This is a continuation of PR #3151 by @matinzd.

Mainly I have:
- Fixed the docs formatting
- Added more edge cases in the tests
- Made it invalid to use durations with just P or nothing after T as per the [Wikipedia page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations)
- However, we still accept decimal values for any unit (eg. P0.5YT1M), even though the standard accepts decimal values only for the last unit specified (eg. P0.5Y)

body:
description
- Issue fixes #916
- Added a new pattern: `exactNDigits`
- Modified `HH`, `mm`, `ss` parser to use exact digits patterns.

comment

- I feagured out that the original flexible digit patterns (twoDigits, threeDigits, fourDigits) are pretty universally used, including `y` and `Y`, as well as the thing kind of `mm`.
- It seems that a new pattern needs to be added to make the `y`, `Y` format also check the digit strictly as they said in the issue.
- But first of all, I wanted to ask your opinion, so I modified only the pattern of `mm`, `ss`, and `hh` format that people need the most in that issue.
- Do you agree to be revised in this direction?

Plus
- In moment.js, strictly can be chosen with a third argument.
```
moment('04:3:00', 'HH:mm:ss', true) // strict
moment('04:3:00', 'HH:mm:ss') // not strict

```
- I think it's better for backward compatibility
- what do think of it?
comments:
I like where it's going! Strict parsing is one of the most requested features, and I want to see it addressed. The way to go is to hide it behind the `strict` option and make it strict in the next major version by default.

Feel free to complete the PR by adding the option and expanding the approach to the rest of the numeric tokens!

@kossnocorp Thank you for comment!

changes

- Added new patterns and utils for strict mode
    - `minNDigits`: specifies only padding (eg.¬†`yyy`¬†-> 001, 012, 123, 1234, ...)
    - `exactNDigits`: specifies the maximum length as well as padding
- Modified it to parse strictly as options

comment

- Normally used minNDigits pattern since the validate method is checking the range of values.
- Tested all tokens I modified but wrote the part of them randomly since they're mostly the same.

body:
This pull request introduces a new Babel plugin, @babel/plugin-transform-optional-chaining, to our project's Babel configuration. The optional chaining feature (?.) provides a concise and robust way to access properties on potentially nullable objects, improving code readability and reducing the risk of runtime errors caused by null or undefined values.

Changes Made:

-   Added @babel/plugin-transform-optional-chaining to the list of plugins in the Babel configuration.
-   Ensured consistency across different environments (CommonJS and ECMAScript Modules) by including the plugin in both configurations.
-   Did not modify any existing code or behavior; this change is additive and does not affect the functionality of the project.

Purpose:

-   Enhance code maintainability and readability by adopting modern JavaScript syntax features.
-   Mitigate potential runtime errors related to null or undefined values.
-   Align our codebase with best practices and industry standards for JavaScript development.
comments: These changes will help a lot for older browsers support. Thank you!

Hey! I appreciate your time, but since v3 dropped IE support and optional chaining has been supported for a long time, it isn't a good idea to get it back. The main reason is that it bloats the build size.

I understand you need to support older browsers, and it's frustrating to deal with, but it's an uphill battle. More and more libraries will do that (I'm pretty conservative about adoption; the presence of CommonJS is proof of that), and you'll have to deal with it again. So, I advise you to transpile your dependencies to target the browsers you need via Babel & Browserslist.

I'm closing the PR unless you have a strong argument about why date-fns must support optional chaining in 2024.

> Second option isn't good at all. Don't know, how much bytes will it cost, to approve this PR. It's up to you, as a member of date-fns team.

It's actually a very good option. From the little I know about what you do, I would recommend processing ALL dependencies to ensure they are compatible with your requirements. It's not unique to date-fns to use modern JS features available in all browsers. Of course, you know better, so take it with a grain of salt.

> Don't know, how much bytes will it cost, to approve this PR. 

It's actually pretty significant, considering optional chaining is probably not the only issue you will encounter.

> Thanks for great lib!

You're welcome!

body:
In README.md file
at line 26 
`format(new Date(2014, 1, 11), "yyyy-MM-dd");`

Actual Output Should be  :   
`//=> '2014-01-11'`

If I provide format values in `FormatDurationOptions` and set `zero` to `true`, I'm expecting also undefined  `Duration` values to be considered in the output.

Example

#### Input

```
formatDuration(
  {
    seconds: 10,
  },
  {
    format: ["hours", "minutes", "seconds"],
    zero: true,
  }
```

#### Actual output:

`10 seconds`

#### Expected output:
Since I've explicitly set hours, minutes, and seconds I'm expecting to see them as 0 in the output.

`0 hours 0 minutes 10 seconds
`

Note: It seems this was working like expected in 2.x but it is not working anymore in 3.x. 
If this is the wanted behaviour instead, I suggest to update the relative [doc](https://date-fns.org/v3.3.1/docs/formatDuration) in order to avoid misleading interpretations of `zero` param.
comments:
Hey! I hate to say it, but merging the PR will break the function for anyone using `zero` right now. Additionally, the `Duration` [doesn't allow `undefined` to be set as property](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/main/src/types.ts#L61-L76) (I realize that not all use TypeScript and set `exactOptionalPropertyTypes`).

Said that, breaking the function behavior was not a good idea to begin with, but let's work with what we have.

Let's hide this behavior behind an option. I feel like `strict` sounds the best as what you expect is to `formatDuration` strictly follow the format and print all units.

The docs can also be more explicit; I would appreciate it if you could update them as well.

What do you think?

body: When using this library in a javascript project, we can pass an amount as a string and when we do that, it generates an incorrect value as it is just concatenating the string ![image](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/assets/9250618/df33d363-d0fe-405a-a999-6076d9f98663) here is where it happens This conversion makes sure that this works and doesn't affect number values. I tried to add a test case, but as it is using TypeScript, it does not allow the string to be passed as a parameter. PS: I am not a javascript developer and if this solution is bad, feel free to provide a better solution or just tell me what could make it better
comments:
Hey! I understand your frustration and will probably disappoint you even more, but I can't accept this PR. I'm sorry for that.

The right solution would be to use `parseInt` or prefix with `+` on your side rather than changing date-fns. You should have control over it, and if you're not confident in your data, it's better to validate or parse it. A more systematic approach to the problem would be to use a type-system that will yell at you when you try to pass a string instead of a number, but I guess it's too much.

I'm closing the PR because introducing an undocumented behavior in one of the many functions that accept number arguments 
will make API less consistent and predictable, which will cause more bugs in the long run.

Even if I were to agree to add this behavior to every function, add tests, and document it (which is a ton of work considering that there are more than 200 functions), the new functions will eventually break it, so it's even more work as it will be yet another item on the checklist that has to be verified manually.

So, a ton of work is needed for a wrong approach to the problem: validate/parse input in the app or use TypeScript.

While I can guess why the change has been made, I won't even try explaining why I can't accept it as I need to know your arguments.

Feel free to justify it, so I can get back to you more thoroughly.

body:
### Problem

When calling `differenceInMonths` from January 31st to February 28th on a leap year, the logic for handling February does not account for the 29th. As a result `intervalToDuration` returns a duration of `1 month, -1 day`.

### Example

```
> differenceInMonths(new Date(2023, 1, 28), new Date(2023, 0, 31))
1
> differenceInMonths(new Date(2024, 1, 28), new Date(2024, 0, 31))
1
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2023, 0, 31), end: new Date(2023, 1, 28) })
{ months: 1 }
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2024, 0, 31), end: new Date(2024, 1, 28) })
{ months: 1, days: -1 }
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2024, 0, 31), end: new Date(2024, 1, 29) })
{ months: 1 }
```
### Expected Output

```
> differenceInMonths(new Date(2023, 1, 28), new Date(2023, 0, 31))
1
> differenceInMonths(new Date(2024, 1, 28), new Date(2024, 0, 31))
0
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2023, 0, 31), end: new Date(2023, 1, 28) })
{ months: 1 }
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2024, 0, 31), end: new Date(2024, 1, 28) })
{ days: 28 }
> intervalToDuration({ start: new Date(2024, 0, 31), end: new Date(2024, 1, 29) })
{ months: 1 }
```

- [x] Ran tests
- [x] Ran linter
comments:
This issue is also affecting formatDistance, when using 1st of February 2024 and 1st of March 2024. This is due to the dependence of the differenceInMonths() as we noticed today in one of our test suits.
![image](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/assets/24392131/9927cf18-8747-4b91-b897-8419a92dbd08)

body:
The PR introduces an optional preprocessor function that lives on the locale.localize object. After the `format` function parses and tokenizes, the preprocessor is invoked with the date and a parts array (the tokens and string literals found in the format string). The preprocessor can modify this array as needed.

This allows us to nicely fix the long standing #1391 french locale day ordinal with long months format regression. This is the best solution I could think of that would not break any public interface and be low overhead. Hope this can benefit other locales too!

As discussed in #3659, I brought back the unit tests from date-fns v1. I also added an additional date and format to the locale snapshots to better surface day ordinal issues (particularly related to the french language) - apologies for the added noise.

![CleanShot 2024-01-10 at 14 42 57@2x](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/assets/4009209/0d9c89d6-8c86-495a-867f-e8b06545f139)

Bonus 1: somewhat unrelated, but working on `format`, I realized that the `_originalDate` argument sent to the formatters was never relevant (both date and options._originalDate were always the same object). I removed this to simplify things a bit.

Bonus 2: Fixed bad import in main branch that was breaking the tests
comments:
For those specifically interested in the french locale fix, here is the isolated code:

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/ddac6a532bcdc4b7b14236d56d936bc0546a403e/src/locale/fr/_lib/localize/index.ts#L127-L148

Just to make sure, https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/3662/files#diff-eda4dba459a77e98278dfef21c803e0e1b94faef1d5a3a3c2b42657b8a4a6e58R128  there is an `Invalid` in the result of parse.
Since it's not the first one in this file I don't think it's blocking, but is it expected ?

> Just to make sure, https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/3662/files#diff-eda4dba459a77e98278dfef21c803e0e1b94faef1d5a3a3c2b42657b8a4a6e58R128 there is an `Invalid` in the result of parse. Since it's not the first one in this file I don't think it's blocking, but is it expected ?

Yes, it's been that way for a while now - I wrote about this in #3136 too
Thanks for the fix and for your time !

> Thanks for the fix and for your time !

Appreciate your review and all the efforts to surface this issue. Hope the approach is sound and we can eventually get this merged!

Oh one other thing I forgot to mention, this only takes into account the `MMM` and `MMMM` tokens which are the **format** context. There are also **stand-alone** context tokens for long months: `LLL` and `LLLL`. Should these also be considered? (I assume not, but wanted to make sure)

https://date-fns.org/docs/format
https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr35/tr35-dates.html#dfst-month
I'm not sure to understand the difference between `LLLL` and `MMMM`, even after reading the documentation part about it. I guess it's not important since it's not for "format" ... üòÑ
Love it, will try to review it carefully and ship with the next version üôè
Shipped with v3.3.0: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/releases/tag/v3.3.0

body: Fixes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1391.
comments:
Thoughts on [my comment in this similar PR](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/2796#issuecomment-981778071)?

It might be less common, but I can see a valid use case (invoicing?) that would use day ordinals without months (ex: 5e du mois / 5e jour du mois). The date-fns v1 implementation was only applying this behavior if day ordinals were followed by `MMM` or `MMMM`, which seems like the safer approach but would require a revamp of the `format` function as far as I can tell.

Also, there used to be unit tests for this edge case in v1. It might be a good idea to bring this back because the locale snapshot tests sometimes don't surface these more subtle issues.

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/67a0329d663f82393261f38c4c47ad65c038bd35/src/locale/fr/build_format_locale/test.js#L299-L328

@fturmel indeed we might want to handle this edge case, but it's much less common so I think it's a good first fix anyway?

And those edge cases are better written using an intl library instead of this one.

The current version does not allow to handle this easily anyway...

Also, I added the test snapshots you suggested :)

Not my call to make, but the concern I want to raise (especially to the non-speaking core team) is the trade-off between breaking valid edge cases that are probably already out there in favor of fixing the more common use case.

I might poke around the `format` function a bit to see if I can find a somewhat sane approach to going back to this v1 behavior.

As mentioned in this PR, this change introduce a regression which is not expected https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1391#issuecomment-530344774
I'm not sure that introduce a regression is better than keep it as it is.
@Dallas62 indeed, that's why @fturmel opened the even better #3662 :)

body:
Closes #3616, #3615, #3588. All .d.mts files were doing an `export type * from` the corresponding .d.ts file. The problem is that not everything is a type but you can't export non-types from a .d.ts.

The simplest and cleanest solution is not to produce .d.mts files and update the exports in the package.json so modules use the .d.ts files. While it's nice to have a .d.mts file name to indicate it's ESM, it's not required especially when it creates other problems.
comments:
It's not a solution as it breaks other environments, see: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/actions/runs/7267702106/job/19804657316?pr=3617

More info: https://github.com/arethetypeswrong/arethetypeswrong.github.io/blob/main/docs/problems/FalseCJS.md

See: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/3618

~~Can someone please produce a minimal reproduction repo? It will help to fix the problem.~~

~~We have a set of different environments [where it's all good](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/actions/runs/7247215749/job/19740705115): https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/tree/main/examples~~

~~Sorry that it slipped!~~
I shipped with the fix with `date-fns@3.0.1`, please try it

Changing the exports in the package.json and not generating the .d.mts files reduces the complexity.

body:
For `Hacktoberfest`, I have been adding `GitHub Codespaces` / `VS Code Remote Containers` configuration for OSS projects to make it easier for contributors to the project to get up and running with the correct developer setup. Including the appropriate configuration for a project allows contributors to work entirely within a web browser via `GH Codespaces`, or inside of fully, and correctly configured containers on their own computer with `VS Code Remote Containers` (both of these use the same configuration, as `GH Codespaces` leverages the `Remote Containers` features under the hood).

For the `date-fns` project, this configuration includes the following:
- Preinstalled `Node LTS`
- Preinstalled `yarn@1.x`
- Preinstalled `ESLint` and `Prettier` extensions
- Preinstalled `playwright` dependencies
- Automation of the `yarn install` when the devcontainer is first created

Basically everything needed for a contributor to open the project after a fresh clone and be immediately productive, either locally with `VS Code` or remotely with `GitHub Codespaces`!

For reference, here are some other repositories for whom I've opened PRs to do the same:

- https://github.com/AnilSeervi/inspirational-quotes/pull/19
- https://github.com/Icon-Shelf/icon-shelf/pull/135 (note that this one is a GUI electron app, but it's still possible to containerize it and do development in the cloud on GH Codespaces!)
- https://github.com/developertools-tech/developertools.tech/issues/36
- https://github.com/floating-ui/floating-ui/pull/2606
- https://github.com/compiler-explorer/compiler-explorer/pull/5631
- https://github.com/EveryBoard/EveryBoard/pull/155
- https://github.com/melt-ui/melt-ui/pull/658
- https://github.com/JamesLMilner/terra-draw/pull/108

When multiple formatting is allowed, for example G, GG and GGG show the era as AD or BC, some people thought this was G..GGG, instead of all 3 possibilities. 
This is improved by showing all possibilities in the list instead of the .. notation that wasn't clear

#3539

Closes #3543 

I used the emails provided in #687 to report a vulnerability but you can also consider [configuring private vulnerability reporting for the repo](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/security-advisories/working-with-repository-security-advisories/configuring-private-vulnerability-reporting-for-a-repository) if you would prefer. Appreciate any feedback!

Besides that, feel free to edit or suggest any changes to this document. It is supposed to reflect the amount of effort the team can offer to handle vulnerabilities.

This pull request adds the ability to set custom business days to the `addBusinessDays`, `subBusinessDays` and `differenceInBusinessDays` functions. It also allows the inclusion of exceptions, or specific dates which should not be considered business days.

The inclusion of exception may resolve #2823.

This fixes the order of the weekdays in polish since it should start with poniedzia≈Çek (monday) and end with niedziela (sunday).

Please check: https://preply.com/en/question/weekdays-in-polish

This adds a `holidays` option to `differenceInBusinessDays`. We count up the number of holidays that are included in the date range (and would otherwise be counted as a business day), and then sub that from the total count of business days.

This fixes the order of the weekdays in spanish since it should start with lunes (monday) and end with domingo (sunday).

Please check:   https://langster.org/en/blog/seasons-days-and-months-in-spanish
comments: I am sorry but langster.org does not count as official evidence. [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Week) reports a very divided scenario according to which I see not enough motivation for the change since we will be making it more misaligned with other countries at the same time.

body:
The single-letter form of `Wednesday` in Spanish is 'X' and not 'M'. 

Quoting [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_Spain): "The Spanish language also has an established convention for days of the week using one letter. These are: L ‚Äì lunes (Monday); M ‚Äì martes (Tuesday); X ‚Äì mi√©rcoles (Wednesday); J ‚Äì jueves (Thursday); V ‚Äì viernes (Friday), S ‚Äì s√°bado (Saturday); and D ‚Äì domingo (Sunday). Each day of the week is written using its first letter except Wednesday, which is represented by the letter X in order to avoid confusion between martes (Tuesday) and mi√©rcoles (Wednesday), which both begin with an m."
comments:
Hi @mindouro thank you for your contribution. I see your point and I agree with your evidence. Nonetheless I have one concern. That use ('x' instead of 'm') makes sense in environments where all days of the week are listed. I am concerned that it makes less sense in isolation - i.e. `x 13 Octubre' looks a bit off.

I would like to have the opinion of other members on this @date-fns/i18n-es

@mindouro You will have to update your PR, there are more files that need changes on order for this to work. Please have a look at the rest of the files i.e. https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/4e5621915afdd1b4cf99009bcc371499eba4857a/src/locale/es/_lib/match/index.ts#L67-L76

body:
#3429 demonstrated that `roundToNearestMinutes()` did not produce expected behaviour. This PR makes a few changes so that `roundToNearestMinutes()` fixes that misbehaviour...

* Previously, there was an inexplicable `addedMinutes` variable which added minutes on to the result. There was no obvious reason for this, and it could only ever cause the result to go wrong: indeed, this seemed to be the chief culprit in the case of #3429. I have removed this variable
* Fixing this behaviour caused the tests to fail. This was because the tests had been engineered to expect the wrong results. I fixed this, and while I was there, removed duplicate tests and replaced test inputs with boundary cases
* Fixing the tests to expect what they ought to expect and putting in boundary cases caused further test failures. This in turn was partly because there was no account made of the milliseconds field of the input. Now, milliseconds are accounted for, which allowed some more of the tests to pass.
* Finally, the remaining issue was that the rounding method was expected to default to `round`, but in fact it was defaulting to `trunc`. I have fixed this as well.

Now, all tests pass, and I have manually checked that this should fix #3429
comments:
I just came across this bug, and was going to submit my own PR, but upon reveiw, @jcarstairs-scottlogic , your PR is perfect and goes even deeper to completely solve the issue.   Great work. **I really hope the maintainers pull it in soon :wink:** 

I note however that the date-fns documentation clearly states that the default rounding method is 'trunc'.  You may need to add the documentation change to your PR.  Although that is a breaking change, it looks like the function hasn't performed correct truncation anyway, so anything you break would have been relying on broken code. :anguished:

Thank you for the PR, I'm working to rebase and finish it.

> Finally, the remaining issue was that the rounding method was expected to default to round, but in fact it was defaulting to trunc. I have fixed this as well.

Trunc is the default behavior across the library, so it should be the default indeed.

Thank you so much for your work. I'll make sure to mention you in the release notes. I used this PR as it adds more edge case tests and also was proposed a bit earlier: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/3132
Shipped with https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/releases/tag/v3.2.0

body:
Previously, `roundToNearestMinutes` accepted `nearestTo` for any and only whole-number values from 1 to 30 inclusive.

This didn't make much sense, for two reasons: one (#3394), that it unfairly excludes the value 60, which is perfectly reasonable; and two, that it allows values like 23, which are pretty nonsensical.

This PR will mean that `roundToNearestMinutes` will accept all and only positive integer values for `nearestTo` which are factors of 60. This will solve #3394. It also makes some improvements to the documentation for `roundToNearestMinutes`.

I don't have first hand experience with this language, but did a bit of research and I think the right identifier for this locale would be `ckb-IQ` or `ckb` (`IQ` is the default region). `ckb` is a subset of `kur` and the identifier is supposed to be `language-REGION`, so `ku-CKB` is probably not right. body:
## Summary

The aim of this PR is to add some context around rounding options for the `differenceInHours` function.

There are other functions which use (all or some of) these options, so there might be a need to duplicate them as necessary. I'm happy to facilitate this and I'm also happy to reformat/reword these changes.

### Summary As you can see in the [International Components for Unicode](https://icu4c-demos.unicode.org/icu-bin/locexp?d_=en&_=fr_CA), the formats `date-fns` uses for the French Canadian locale date and time formats are incorrect. I propose we update the French Canadian date and time styling to use the most up to date formats from the ICU, just as `Intl` does today. I've also regenerated the snapshot.md for French Canadian, let me know if there is anything else that is needed to make this change. Thanks ### Reproduction [Here is a small reproduction](https://codesandbox.io/s/date-fns-fr-ca-demo-t1rhpj?file=/src/App.js) that demonstrates the problem visually comparing `fr-CA` to `date-fns` and `Intl` timestyles. ### ICU Data Snapshot

body: Related Issue: #3380 This PR fixes the issue where Arabic time formats aren't parsed correctly. Verified this fix in the date-fns REPL: This is what `parse` returns for a standard Arabic time expression before this fix:

Standalone period names are only usable in a sentence, but not in standalone text. Also their English locale equivalent also states the number 1 in front of the period name.

Adding 1 to the period name does not break current usage, but adds usability.

Consider following Czech sentence, which retains same meaning, possibly adding more readability:

 Zb√Ωv√° {{distance}} ‚Äì Zb√Ωv√° hodina 40 minut. -> Zb√Ωv√° 1 hodina 40 minut.

Consider following GUI, which currently is not usable and gains usability: 

‚è±Ô∏è {{distance}} ‚Äì ‚è±Ô∏è hodina 40 minut -> ‚è±Ô∏è 1 hodina 40 minut

That is the reason to include the extra 1 in front of the period name.

body:
Short date format for nl-BE uses slash `/` instead of `.`. 

source: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/db2/11.5?topic=considerations-date-time-formats-by-territory-code

This pull request is to align the Estonian locale (et) implementation of `formatRelative` with the English one, more precisely the `nextWeek` case.

For an English locale, the `nextWeek` case would output for example `Sunday at 12:00 PM`.
The current et locale version outputs `j√§rgmine p√ºhap√§ev kell 12:00`, which in direct translation is `next Sunday at 12:00 PM`.

This in my opinion is not what I'd expect following the docs, as this is misunderstood as the *next* Sunday as in the next week, not the *upcoming* Sunday in the current week.

My proposal is to remove the "j√§rgmine" word so that the output aligns more with the default locale.
So the output would be "p√ºhap√§ev kell 12:00".

_Note: as Estonian speakers know, this part of the language is pretty subjective. For example "j√§rgmine reede" can be interpreted differently by each speaker, it's more of a cultural thing. My proposed variant is less subjective (which is a good thing imo), but makes combining the output of formatRelative a bit harder to use in a sentence that answers "Millal?". But I'd say it's a net positive tradeoff._

- Don't try to convert to date

Benchmark code:
```ts
import Benchmark from 'benchmark';
const isValidNew = require('./src/isValid').default
const isValidOld = require('./src/isValidOld').default

const testsFunctions = {
  "old isValid": {
    test: (date) => isValidOld(date)
  },
  "new isValid": {
    test: (date) => isValidNew(date)
  },
};

const dates = [
  new Date(''),
  new Date(),
  Date.now(),
  new Date(NaN),
]

dates.forEach(date => {
  const suite = new Benchmark.Suite;

  console.log('Testing with', date)
  Object.values(testsFunctions).forEach(test => console.log(test.test(date)))
  Object.entries(testsFunctions).forEach(([name, test]) => suite.add(name, () => test.test(date)))
  suite
    .on('cycle', (event) => console.log(String(event.target)))
    .on('complete', () => console.log(''))
    .run();
});

```

body:
I18n (minor): This reverts a change made in https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/1105 regarding the comma between date and time for `de` and `de-AT` locales. 

While the DIN-5008 specification was referenced, there is no explicit mention of numeric date and time (specifically, the format `Pp`). A client of mine filed a bug with me because they were missing a comma between date and time, so I did some research and found [sources](https://dict.leo.org/grammatik/deutsch/Rechtschreibung/Regeln/Interpunktion/Komma/Angaben.xml?lang=de) stating that any date and time parts should be joined with a comma, much like e.g. in `en-US`. Also, [Intl.DateTimeFormat](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Intl/DateTimeFormat) uses a comma (see [repro in codepen](https://codepen.io/felix-scale/pen/VwBLYWj)).

In my opinion, commas should be added back to align the behavior with user expectations and Intl.DateTimeFormat.

I implemented a function to determine whether it is a weekday or not.

This function is  the opposite of [isWeekend](https://date-fns.org/v2.29.3/docs/isWeekend).
Clarifies some documentation as mentioned in #2888

Date time formats in the NL do not have a comma in the format.
Can be verified by https://st.unicode.org/cldr-apps/v#/nl/Gregorian/43da060150c3ffc1

This pull requests fixes the (german) issue [#3275](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/3275#issuecomment-1316944439) when the locale dateformats are used as placeholders in UI components. The spelling is not the expected format in german (see [german DIN 5008](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datumsformat#DIN_5008))

>√Ñhnlich wie in den meisten anderen europ√§ischen L√§ndern wurde die Norm auch in Deutschland und √ñsterreich weitgehend ignoriert, wo allgemein weiterhin das gewohnte Format TT.MM.[JJ]JJ in Gebrauch blieb.
>
> (Translated: Similar to most other European countries, the standard was largely ignored in Germany and Austria, where generally the familiar format DD.MM.[YY]YY remained in use.)

Previously and after this change, the formatted dates are still the same (snapshot tests passing):
* previous short format `dd.MM.y` creates for example `07.01.2018`
* the updated format `dd.MM.yyyy` is fitting the german spelling and still creates for example `07.01.2018`.

As per the contributing guildelines, I've converted localeSnapshots to TypeScript.

This mostly worked as it was, but I've also made a couple of minor fixes to make it more inline with best practice TypeScript.

In the process of fixing #3204, I found it is difficult to determine the specific differences between a snapshot and the output of the current code.

This change makes it easier by adding the conflicting lines to the error message.

Example output:
```node ‚ûú /workspaces/date-fns (main ‚úó) $ yarn locale-snapshots test
yarn run v1.22.19
$ env TZ=utc babel-node --extensions .ts,.js ./scripts/build/localeSnapshots/index.js test
Error: The snapshot on the disk doesn't match the generated snapshot: /workspaces/date-fns/src/locale/en-NZ/snapshot.md. Please run yarn locale-snapshots and commit the results.
Line 530:
-| {"seconds":2} | 2 secondos|
+| {"seconds":2} | 2 seconds |
    at /workspaces/date-fns/scripts/build/localeSnapshots/index.js:65:21
    at async Promise.all (index 25)
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.```

Lithuanian uses a different form of 'seconds' for numbers ending in 1. This change handles that form.

Fixes #3204

body:
Added a new formatter to get week of the month.

closes #1134

### Usage
```
var format = require('date-fns/format')
const date = new Date(1986, 3 /* Apr */, 6) // 2nd week of the month
console.log(format(date, 'W Wo WW')) // 2 2nd 02
console.log(format(date, "Wo 'week of' MMMM YYY")) // 2nd week of April 1986
```

body: Very minor fix to spelling in the test, no logic changes.

This fixes #3194 by simply rounding down the fractional seconds to the nearest millisecond. Consider the two cases below:

| ISO string                    | `timestamp` = date part | `time` = milliseconds part | `timestamp`+`time` |
| ----------------------------- | ----------------------: | -------------------------- | ------------------ |
| `2014-02-11T11:30:30.999999`  |           1392076800000 | 41430999.999               | 1392118230999.999  |
| `2014-02-11T11:30:30.9999999` |           1392076800000 | 41430999.9999              | 1392118231000      |

In the second case the sum of `timestamp` and `time` is incorrectly rounded up because of the limited precision of JavaScript numbers. Rounding down the `time` part explicitly ensures consistent handling of such cases.

I assumed that `getMonth` would return the natural month number, not the Javascript month number. Checking the docs it wasn't super obvious either, as it's not mentioned and `new Date(2012, 1, 29)` in the example reads like the 29th of January. I think this has tripped others up too (#2975 & #768).

This PR makes it clear in the description of the docs that January = 0 and it also updates the example to use `new Date('2012-02-29')` so the date reads more naturally.

body: In both the nl-BE and nl locale, Friday (vrijdag) is abbreviated to 'vri'. The 'ij' in 'vrijdag' is a digraph and should not be cut in two. Instead, 'vrijdag' should be abbreviated to 'vrij'. If abbreviations must strictly be three characters, the unicode character 'ƒ≥' could be used instead, but this character is not well-supported.

Is there any hope to get this in?

Alright, fair enough

First of all, thanks a lot for this workaround.
It seems like parsing of negative durations doesn't work.
```
parseISODuration('P-1D');

// results in Invalid format
```
Is it on purpose? Can this be added to this feature as well? It is supported in libs like luxon or dayjs, so technically it may be possible. Here is an example of luxon and dayjs if you want live example:
https://codesandbox.io/s/dazzling-liskov-4dqzg5?file=/src/App.tsx

> First of all, thanks a lot for this workaround. It seems like parsing of negative durations doesn't work.
> 
> ```
> parseISODuration('P-1D');
> 
> // results in Invalid format
> ```
> 
> Is it on purpose? Can this be added to this feature as well? It is supported in libs like luxon or dayjs, so technically it may be possible. Here is an example of luxon and dayjs if you want live example: https://codesandbox.io/s/dazzling-liskov-4dqzg5?file=/src/App.tsx

According to the [specification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#:~:text=Durations%20define%20the,number%20of%20seconds.) all these values are positive and above zero. In my understanding I would assume we should not have a negative day or negative year?

> > First of all, thanks a lot for this workaround. It seems like parsing of negative durations doesn't work.
> > ```
> > parseISODuration('P-1D');

Agree, but it was the same discussion in other libraries (sorry to link to other libs from here, but this is the one of many discussions: https://github.com/moment/moment/issues/2408#issue-85650097) Don't mean that if others support it, date-fns must support it - just curious about the roadmap.
Any chance to get the conflicts resolved so we can still get this into v3?

@matinzd don't worry about the docs. Adding more tests never hurt, if you feel there's something to cover please go ahead.
What is missing so this can be merged? Anything I can do to help?

There are some test cases that the current implementation is not covering. I will try to update the PR accordingly.

@yjukaku Yes, you are right! The test case I found was not related to supporting negative values. Also negative values are not in the standard as far as I checked. 
I really want to be mindful when merging the PR because I don't want people to use a broken function in their codebase especially that date-fns is widely used in the ecosystem.

Closes #3129

The recent addition of the `roundingMethod` option (#3091) was not implemented correctly, and some unit tests were not checking for the right behavior. This PR fixes the problems, adds several unit tests, improves the JS docs and adds two additional examples.

I've also internally renamed the `getRoundingMethod` file and made the function as a default export for consistency to match other functions in the library.

body:
This PR fixes the ESM `import` in Node.js environment. Close https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/2964. 

Let's say you have files with the following content:

```
// m.mjs
import format from 'date-fns/esm/format/index.js'

console.log(format(new Date(), 'yyyy-MM-dd'))
```

```
// c.cjs
const { format } = require('date-fns')
const format2 = require('date-fns/format')

console.log(format(new Date(), 'yyyy-MM-dd'))
console.log(format2(new Date(), 'yyyy-MM-dd'))
```

Before this PR:

```
$ node c.cjs
2022-06-27
2022-06-27

$ node m.mjs
(node:19584) Warning: To load an ES module, set "type": "module" in the package.json or use the .mjs extension.
(Use `node --trace-warnings ...` to show where the warning was created)
/private/tmp/date-fns-play/node_modules/date-fns/esm/format/index.js:1
import isValid from "../isValid/index.js";
^^^^^^

SyntaxError: Cannot use import statement outside a module
    at Object.compileFunction (node:vm:352:18)
    at wrapSafe (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1033:15)
    at Module._compile (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1069:27)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1159:10)
    at Module.load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:981:32)
    at Function.Module._load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:822:12)
    at ModuleWrap.<anonymous> (node:internal/modules/esm/translators:170:29)
    at ModuleJob.run (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:198:25)
    at async Promise.all (index 0)
    at async ESMLoader.import (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:385:24)
```

After this PR:

```
$ node c.cjs
2022-06-27
2022-06-27

$ node m.mjs
2022-06-27
```



---

This PR added `node_modules/date-fns/esm/package.json`, with the content `{"type": "module"}`.

This PR modified 587 files under `node_modules/date-fns/esm/`, added the content `"type": "module"` to them.

body:
Related to #3073

Some performance improvements.

Benchmark results:
```
differenceInMilliseconds OLD x 8,676,903 ops/sec ¬±0.26% (101 runs sampled)
differenceInMilliseconds NEW x 48,903,652 ops/sec ¬±0.16% (102 runs sampled)

addMilliseconds OLD x 7,602,302 ops/sec ¬±0.23% (101 runs sampled)
addMilliseconds NEW x 15,289,752 ops/sec ¬±0.20% (100 runs sampled)

getTime OLD x 12,598,385 ops/sec ¬±0.27% (99 runs sampled)
getTime NEW x 64,110,631 ops/sec ¬±0.11% (99 runs sampled)

toDate OLD x 12,834,366 ops/sec ¬±0.16% (96 runs sampled)
toDate NEW x 14,783,712 ops/sec ¬±0.23% (97 runs sampled)

differenceInMinutes OLD x 7,205,386 ops/sec ¬±0.26% (100 runs sampled)
differenceInMinutes NEW x 46,375,959 ops/sec ¬±0.25% (98 runs sampled)

differenceInHours OLD x 7,223,554 ops/sec ¬±0.30% (94 runs sampled)
differenceInHours NEW x 38,381,831 ops/sec ¬±0.72% (90 runs sampled)

addHours OLD x 7,376,076 ops/sec ¬±0.32% (100 runs sampled)
addHours NEW x 15,235,834 ops/sec ¬±0.20% (98 runs sampled)

addWeeks OLD x 6,748,790 ops/sec ¬±0.32% (98 runs sampled)
addWeeks NEW x 7,406,296 ops/sec ¬±0.25% (101 runs sampled)

getUnixTime OLD x 11,995,158 ops/sec ¬±0.23% (95 runs sampled)
getUnixTime NEW x 47,958,027 ops/sec ¬±0.70% (98 runs sampled)
```

Benchmark code:
```js
import Benchmark from 'benchmark';
import fnsOld from 'date-fns';
import fnsNew from './date-fns-new/index.js';

const leftDate = new Date();
const rightDate = fnsOld.addHours(new Date(), 453);

const testsFunctions = [
  // changed functions
  ['differenceInMilliseconds', [leftDate, rightDate]],
  ['addMilliseconds', [leftDate, 1442342]],
  ['getTime', [leftDate]],
  ['toDate', [leftDate]],
  // some related functions
  ['differenceInMinutes', [leftDate, rightDate]],
  ['differenceInHours', [leftDate, rightDate]],
  ['addHours', [leftDate, 14]],
  ['addWeeks', [leftDate, 5]],
  ['getUnixTime', [leftDate]],
];

testsFunctions.forEach(([funcName, args]) => {
  const suite = new Benchmark.Suite;

  suite
    .add(`${funcName} OLD`, () => fnsOld[funcName](...args))
    .add(`${funcName} NEW`, () => fnsNew[funcName](...args))
    .on('cycle', (event) => console.log(String(event.target)))
    .on('complete', () => console.log(''))
    .run();
});
```

Added an optional field to options on `roundToNearestMinutes` to toggle between `Math.floor` and `Math.ceil`, with default on `floor`.

body:
This PR fixes #3060.

Added an optional flag that gets rid of all the values with 0 to have a shorter (but still valid) ISO duration string.

The case where only `minutes` are present is also handled, rendering them with `TxM` instead of the usual `xM` to avoid ambiguity with `months`.

body:
- This integrates the `UTCDate` class (https://github.com/date-fns/utc) that replaces internal UTC functions making the build size smaller.
- It makes all functions that accept `Date` as an argument generic. This allows using any class that extends `Date`.
- It also updates TypeScript config and forces using `index` in imports

body:
Whenever I want to check if I need to specify the locale for some date-fns usage, I find it useful to have a sorted fn names listed out.

This PR pulls out the function names as a list from the properties section and put them in the description section of `Locale`. 

I'm unable to figure out letting the docs server reading the local `docs.json`, so the formats of the description section might be off.

Please feel free to edit or close this PR. Thank you for the great library!

----

## Description

If you're using any of these date-fns, consider specifying a locale in options:

- `differenceInCalendarWeeks`
- `eachWeekOfInterval`
- `endOfWeek`
- `format`
- `formatDistance`
- `formatDistanceStrict`
- `formatRelative`
- `getWeek`
- `getWeekOfMonth`
- `getWeeksInMonth`
- `getWeekYear`
- `isMatch`
- `isSameWeek`
- `isThisWeek`
- `lastDayOfWeek`
- `parse`
- `setDay`
- `setWeek`
- `setWeekYear`
- `startOfWeek`
- `startOfWeekYear`

Read the Properties section below for more details.

## Screenshots

![JPEG-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/922234/170183072-1ce8743e-4388-4cf9-b71a-d5f4e4b77fba.jpg)
commit_messages: Update Locale docs description to include a sorted list of fns (#3062)

body:
Issue #2968 mentioning `formatISO` doesn't support millisecond yet. The JS `Date.toISOString()` return millisecond with `.` (dot)

```
new Date().toISOString() // 2022-02-27T14:26:49.139Z
```

But after reading from Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601, I can't find any implementation on millisecond. Should we do this by default? Or we can use options?

```
formatISO(date, { withMillisecond: true })
```
comments:
> But after reading from Wikipedia [en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601), I can't find any implementation on millisecond. Should we do this by default? Or we can use options?

It seems that some languages include milliseconds while others do not. It's possible that the milliseconds are implied as part of the seconds: "seconds with decimals".

We should probably rely on EcmaScript‚Äôs specification and usage of the standard: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-date-time-string-format

> ECMAScript defines a string interchange format for date-times based upon a simplification of the ISO 8601 calendar date extended format. The format is as follows: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ`

> When you have the time, could you also update the tests for the IST as well?

I'm still confused on how to update the IST test, could you point me out where?

See companion PR #2948

This PR should get rid of all remaining linting errors caught by these new rules, except for one missing d.ts file that should get resolved by merging #2941

This PR brings linter improvements and fixes. The current eslint configuration is not working very well...

**Overview**
- isolates the linter checks in their own Github CI action
- fixes a number of eslint problems
- adds eslint rules that are sensible to the project's overall style (some are warning only so the CI can pass with the `--quiet` flag)
- adds supplemental type checking with `tsc`
- updates CONTRIBUTING.md

**Dependencies**
- upgrade to eslint 8
- replace `babel-eslint` with `@babel/eslint-parser` (the library moved)
- added `@babel/plugin-proposal-class-properties` and `@babel/plugin-transform-shorthand-properties` because they are used in the project directly, and they are transitive deps at the moment
- bump all eslint and babel related packages to latest
- bump prettier, typescript and ts-node to latest
- bump lint-staged to latest, specifically to get rid of the `date-fns` v1 transitive dep because it causes linting issues

Companion PR #2949 should get rid of remaining linting errors caught by these rules.

A follow-up to this would be to review all `eslint-disable` comments in the source code and evaluate if they are needed or not. Some were introduced to bypass false-positives because JavaScript rules were scanning TypeScript code with the current configuration.

Without this change, when I run the build script, I get this error:

```
ÓÇ∞ ./scripts/build/build.sh
+ ./scripts/build/docs.js
+ ./scripts/build/fp.ts
env: ts-node: No such file or directory
```

By specifying `yarn ts-node`, it'll enforce usage of the `ts-node` version defined in `package.json` and `yarn.lock`.

@leshakoss if you're wondering why the tests are failing, `this` doesn't refer to the same scope inside a function vs inside an arrow function.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Arrow_functions

> [...] does not have its own bindings to **this** or **super**, and should not be used as methods.

https://mochajs.org/#arrow-functions

> Passing arrow functions (aka ‚Äúlambdas‚Äù) to Mocha is discouraged. Lambdas lexically bind **this** and cannot access the Mocha context.
This PR continues work started in #2476 and #2005

body:
Let's start the new year with a bang! Hope this isn't too unwieldy, but I opted for one migration per commit (easier reviews) and one PR as to not flood the project with 50+ individual PRs.

I worked with diffs of the `en-US` locale for every single file to try to keep the reference implementation's code shape when possible.

**Overview**

- all remaining locales were migrated to TS except for `fil` which has been broken for a while, and `uk` which already had an approved PR
- fixed a few previously migrated locales that had type issues
- the `nn` and `sv` locales support `options.onlyNumeric` in `formatDistance`, so I added it to the `FormatDistanceOptions` type

**Snapshot.md file changes (6 locales total)**

- Fixed issue parsing months in `hr`, `ka`, `sr` and `sr-Latn`
- Fixed issue parsing day of week in `ka`
- Fixed weeks support in `formatDuration` of `kk`
- I _believe_ I fixed a code issue in the `lt` locale's `formatDistance` that prevented it from using future tense with suffixes. I don't speak the language, so could someone confirm this is OK? Hard-coding [this constant](https://github.com/fturmel/date-fns/blob/b5cddfb54d7a8af59435cbd23339ca02d5534186/src/locale/lt/_lib/formatDistance/index.ts#L161) to `false` reverts to the old behavior. @date-fns/i18n-lt

body:
This PR converts the documentation generation code to TypeScript and adds a new dynamically generated documentation page that lists available locales as a table and as JSON. I think this will be very valuable to the community to have easy access to this information.

You can preview the generated page here: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/9bb51691f201c3ec05ab832acbc5d478f2e5c47a/docs/i18nLocales.md

A few things to point out:

- I turned on the `jsdoc-to-markdown` cache, as it seems to work well and detects file changes correctly. On my machine, it takes almost 2 minutes on an empty cache to generate the docs, but completes in 420ms with cache and one source file modified.
- This new docs generation script will fail if the `@summary` jsdoc tags of locales are not unique. Hoping this will help people build out locale selectors without duplicate entries. I made some adjustments to a few locale's jsdoc entries to fix typos, uniqueness and precision.
- To complete the TypeScript conversion, I had to add some type definitions to `package.json`. I kept the changes to a minimum.

Hope you like it!

EDIT: also fixes a docs bug for FP ESM usage, [see comment below](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/2838#issuecomment-991941546)

Dead simple getter / setter function to globally access the default locale that all functions use. No breaking changes.

This is one of the most requested features in `date-fns` by the community, hopefully this will get seriously considered. Happy to collaborate on this if the implementation doesn't fit the team's vision.

As @olee [wrote](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/816#issuecomment-975149577), _"there is already a global state of locale - it is just that it is hardcoded to be the english locale"_.

comments: Hi @date-fns/i18n-fr. Tried to make ordinal day of the month formatter more useful and fix #1391. I feel like this should cover more `format` use cases than not having this fix at all. Am I correct? This is how moment.js behaves too.

@leshakoss I'm on the fence personally.

As pointed out [here](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1391#issuecomment-530344774) there are some formatting scenarios where the current behavior is fine, and this PR could be a breaking change for many.

The following are correct formattings. Your PR would enable the use of `do` in case 3 (more common as you pointed out), but break case 1.
1. `le 2√®me jour du mois`
2. `le 1er jour du mois`
3. `le 2 novembre`
4. `le 1er novembre`

In v1, this conditional logic was only applied if `do` was immediately followed by `MMMM`.

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/67a0329d663f82393261f38c4c47ad65c038bd35/src/locale/fr/build_format_locale/index.js#L80-L98

CLDR says `y-MM-dd` is correct https://www.unicode.org/cldr/cldr-aux/charts/32/summary/sv.html#1939, it also makes little difference in a real world case. E.g. `2021-11-30` is formated the same way, it only makes a difference for dates like `0001-12-24` etc. So I would be in favour of keep using the CLDR suggested format

2024-04-25T02:00:00.000Z

### Environment

```console

v18.13.0
$ cat package.json | jq -c .dependencies
{"date-fns":"^3.6.0"}
```

body: Fixes #2001

We call Saturday and Sunday as Ï£ºÎßê(ÈÄ±Êú´). Ï£º(ÈÄ±) means "week" and Îßê(Êú´) means "end".
So you can see that Sunday is the last day of a week in Korean language.
comments: Hi @date-fns/i18n-ko could you please confirm that this is correct? `weekStartsOn` affects calculation of week-related functions like `isSameWeek` for example.

https://korean.go.kr/front/onlineQna/onlineQnaView.do?mn_id=216&qna_seq=218209&pageIndex=1

The official answer of the National Institute of Korean Language is that the start of the week is Monday.

However, I think changing that `weekStartsOn` will change all the week-related calculations. I think this is likely to create too many breaking changes. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/357619/143968244-67d70274-d15e-4a40-8f80-6ba28074fe12.png)

Koreans think that the start of the week is 54% on Mondays and 43% on Sundays according to the survey, so apps such as calendars generally start Sunday and then add options to change to Monday. I think there may be a risk when the result values of functions such as `isSameWeek()` become different from before.

I think I'll have to look more at how much this change will affect.

NIKL is not an organisation that standardize specs on this kind.
Should look at KS(Korean Standard) spec (KS X ISO8601).
https://standard.go.kr/KSCI/standardIntro/getStandardSearchView.do?menuId=503&topMenuId=502&ksNo=KSXISO8601&tmprKsNo=KSXISO8601&reformNo=03
Which also specifying that Monday is the first day of the week.
> 2.2.8
> Ïó≠Ï£º (Calendar week)
> Ïó≠ÎÖÑ Ï§ëÏùò ÏÑúÏàòÏóê ÏùòÌïòÏó¨ ÏßÄÏ†ïÎêòÎäî ÌäπÏ†ïÌïú 7ÏùºÏùò Í∏∞Í∞ÑÏúºÎ°ú ÏõîÏöîÏùºÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÏãúÏûëÎêúÎã§.

> NIKL is not an organisation that standardize specs on this kind. Should look at KS(Korean Standard) spec (KS X ISO8601).

KS X ISO 8601 is, uh, just a localized version of ISO 8601. The ISO 8601 week calendar is distinct to other widely used week calendars; technically speaking it's a [leap week calendar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_week_calendar) with a different year grouping compared to other calendars which limits its uses (it even triggered a [Twitter bug](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/dec/29/twitter-2015-date-bug) back in 2014). As such it is irrelevant for this discussion.

KS X ISO 8601ÏùÄ... Í∑∏ÎÉ• ISO 8601Ïùò ÏßÄÏó≠ÌôîÎêú Î≤ÑÏ†ÑÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ISO 8601 Ï£ºÍ∞Ñ Îã¨Î†•ÏùÄ Îã§Î•∏ ÎÑêÎ¶¨ Ïì∞Ïù¥Îäî Ï£ºÍ∞Ñ Îã¨Î†•Í≥ºÎäî Î≥ÑÍ∞úÏùò Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏù∏Îç∞, Í∏∞Ïà†Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎßêÌïòÏûêÎ©¥ [Ïú§Ï£º Îã¨Î†•](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_week_calendar)Ïù¥Îùº Ìï¥ÏÑú Ìïú Ìï¥Ïùò ÏãúÏûëÍ≥º ÎÅùÏù¥ Îã§Î•∏ Îã¨Î†•Í≥º Îã§Î•¥Í≤å Ïû°ÌòÄ ÏûàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ïì∏Î™®Í∞Ä Ï†úÌïúÎê©ÎãàÎã§(Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ 2014ÎÖÑÏóêÎäî Ïù¥Í≤É ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê [Ìä∏ÏúÑÌÑ∞ Î≤ÑÍ∑∏](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/dec/29/twitter-2015-date-bug)Í∞Ä ÎÇòÍ∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÍ≥†Ïöî). Í∑∏Îü¨Îãà Ïù¥ ÌëúÏ§ÄÏùÄ ÌòÑ ÎÖºÏùòÏóêÏÑúÎäî Î¨¥Í¥ÄÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

[Unicode CLDR](https://unicode-org.github.io/cldr-staging/charts/latest/supplemental/territory_information.html) has "First day of week" data. For South Korea, it is Sunday.

I know nothing about date-fns project's policy, but relying on the external (authorative?) source would be more productive than discussing about each locale's case in this project.

Maybe related: https://github.com/tc39/ecma402/issues/6
In that case, we'll keep it the same as in CLDR (i.e. Sunday). Thanks!

body:
See #1801

This should allow usage of the generated flow types in flow strict environments.

The only actual change here is:

```diff
diff --git a/scripts/build/_lib/typings/formatBlock.js b/scripts/build/_lib/typings/formatBlock.js
index 4e1aa32e..4fa3f47c 100644
--- a/scripts/build/_lib/typings/formatBlock.js
+++ b/scripts/build/_lib/typings/formatBlock.js
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-const flowHeader = '// @flow'
+const flowHeader = '// @flow strict'
 const generatedAutomaticallyMessage = "// This file is generated automatically by `scripts/build/typings.js`. Please, don't change it."
 
 const id = x => x
```

But apparently the repo wants to prettify this file :man_shrugging:
comments: Sorry for reiterating the question. I'm not sure I understand well how it works. Could you please tell me how this will affect users that don't use the strict mode? Would they have to change their code?

After looking into this again, I've come to the conclusion that this change will introduce new flow errors for any users who have strict mode configured with `unclear-type` because of the liberal use of `any` in the `date-fns` types. In theory any users who don't have strict mode configured would not get any new errors, but users of strict mode would get new errors from `date-fns` files for any lint rules they have in their strict mode config that `date-fns` would not conform to, including `unclear-type` which is likely the most common strict mode lint.

In theory the only way to ensure that the types from `date-fns` would not introduce errors in any strict mode config would be to refine the types such that with every lint that flow offers turned on, a flow check would result in no errors or warnings. 

A more reasonable course of action would likely be to strive to conform to a reasonable set of lint rules. Flow [recommends a basic set of lint rules](https://flow.org/en/docs/strict/#toc-features) for strict mode in their docs. This would certainly be a lot of work given the current state of the types.

comments: My bad, parseISO returns a Date. See the issue.

body:
Related Issues:
- https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/376
- https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/2484
- https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/2151
- https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1604

The current implementation of `isSameMonth` didn't respect the timezones.

```js
const january = new Date('2015-02-01T00:00:00.000+01:00')
const february = new Date('2015-02-01T00:00:00.000Z')

// Current behavior 
_.isSameMonth(january, february)
true

// Expected behavior
_.isSameMonth(january, february)
false
```
comments:
This doesn't look correct.

`Date` object doesn't store the timezone it has been created with. In fact `Date` is basically a wrapper over a single value, the date's timestamp. `isSameMonth(january, february)` does return `true` for me, but that is because in my timezone both dates happen to refer to the same day.

```
const january = new Date('2015-02-01T00:00:00.000+01:00')
const february = new Date('2015-02-01T00:00:00.000Z')
isSameMonth(january, february) //=> true
january.toString() //=> "Sun Feb 01 2015 00:00:00 GMT+0100 (CET)"
february.toString() //=> "Sun Feb 01 2015 01:00:00 GMT+0100 (CET)"
```

> isSameMonth(january, february) does return true for me, but that is because in my timezone both dates happen to refer to the same day.

Exactly my point. As dates operates on UTC, it should use the utc based operations  for `isSameMonth` to be completely deterministic in all the browsers and ignoring client time zones.

This should be covered by implementing utc support for `isSameMonth` similar to https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/src/_lib/isSameUTCWeek/index.ts

The docs mention something about that, but it's not really working.
`date-fns/utc` doesn't exist in the module.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/431376/143257236-f8e8c4ed-3de9-4e2a-9b9a-7ec08e5cbf21.png)

What are the plans for that and [#1458 ](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/376)?

body:
This is an improved implementation of the `clamp` function.

- approx. 45% faster perf (1.8MM vs 2.6MM ops/sec)
- slightly smaller overall file size by removing min/max imports
- fix missing import of Interval type
- RangeErrors for date and interval arguments
- added `eslint-env mocha` to test file to remove eslint errors

Closes #2611
Closes #1778
Closes #2470
Closes #2910

By using `add` internally instead of `sub`, the `intervalToDuration` function gives better results for end of month interval start dates while still passing all existing unit tests. It also means better interop with `add`, as discussed in #2611.

Before:
```js
intervalToDuration({start: new Date(2021, 7, 31), end: new Date(2021, 8, 30)})
// {years: 0, months: 0, days: 30, hours: 0, minutes: 0, seconds: 0}
```

With this PR:
```js
intervalToDuration({start: new Date(2021, 7, 31), end: new Date(2021, 8, 30)})
// {years: 0, months: 1, days: 0, hours: 0, minutes: 0, seconds: 0}
```

This also brings a few improvements:
- new RangeError thrown if interval start date is greater than end date. This is standard in all other functions handling intervals and per https://date-fns.org/docs/Interval
- additional unit tests covering new edge cases and thrown exceptions
- leaner implementation: removed dependencies to `compareAsc` and `isValid`, removed sign and Math.abs operations that were not required.
comments: lmk what you think of my suggestion of keeping func signature as-is and feel free to tag me for a +1
@nsafai Thanks for taking the time and all the nice notes! As I replied in my comments I think the function signature is intact but let me know if I'm missing something.
Thanks for the fix but it's a breaking change because of the Math.abs removal. Please bump a major version next time.
@hiendaovinh sorry, that was not supposed to happen :[ A patch with a revert coming soon

@hiendaovinh actually, I don't think this is a breaking change. If interval.start was after interval.end the function would've thrown a RangeError anyway, so there's no way to get negative values from the function. If I'm wrong, please provide a test case that we can use to verify this üôá

>  If interval.start was after interval.end the function would've thrown a RangeError anyway

@leshakoss The RangeError was introduced in this PR, so if there are any breaking changes that would be it. However that error should've always been there if you look at the behavior of every other functions accepting an Interval in the library, per my PR notes.

Ah, I see. Honestly, this is a tough call. I would count this as a bug fix rather than a breaking change, but that's maybe because I already have "interval.start is not supposed to be after interval.end" in mind, but I understand why one might think the opposite

I do understand and I share the same thinking without regarding the "interval.start is not supposed to be after interval.end" stuff. Actually one of my colleges had a bug switching their places so I knew :laughing:. It's certainly a bug fix but also a breaking change in its own way. That' interesting.
@hiendaovinh reverted the change in v2.29.2: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/releases/tag/v2.29.2

comments:
Unfortunately it's not that easy. `typings.d.ts` is generated by `/scripts/build/typings.js` and uses the jsdocs in each functions. They need to remain compatible with JS, TS and Flow. Lots of changes required.

Also, if you look at the docs the correct predicate for `isValid` would be `is Date | number`. #2308 is a move in the right direction but will not change the output of `typings.d.ts` until either the build system is updated or the project switches to use `tsc` to generate `.d.ts` files.

body:
This brings a number of improvements and fixes related to the new Deno package build, which is partially broken at the moment. See https://github.com/date-fns/deno/pull/2

## Fixes
- ~remove the broken locales from output~ (not relevant anymore)
- remove typings.d.ts and *.d.ts from output (they are incompatible with Deno when referenced using `@deno-types`)
- addDenoExtensions build:
  - correctly resolve the file path for imports that reference a directory instead of a file
  - stricter path replace to avoid transforming an import multiple times (ex: `../../types.ts` and `../../../types.ts` in same file)
  - script will now fail if it can't locate a file for an import/export path
  - early exit check in core loop was always a miss because it was using `importPath` instead of `fullPath`
  - minor optimizations
- fix all bad imports in the project (missing types, typos)

## Tests
- added a Deno test which simple runs a few assertions and imports the whole library
- added a Deno github action that builds and tests the Deno package on pull requests/push
- Jest config ignore `test/deno` path
comments:
@fturmel 
thank you! @kossnocorp can you please have a look?
@fturmel any chance to use this from deno without waiting to be merged?

@vizcay not directly from a CDN, but you could clone my branch, build the Deno files and copy them to your app temporarily if you can't wait for an official release.

Here are the steps to follow (assuming you have Node and Deno installed on that machine):

```bash
# clone & checkout the PR branch
git clone git@github.com:fturmel/date-fns.git
cd date-fns
git checkout PR/deno-fixes

# build & test Deno version
yarn install
./scripts/build/deno.sh
./scripts/test/deno.sh
```

If the build and test shell scripts run successfully, you can copy the content of the `date-fns/deno` directory in your project and import the lib with a relative path. Here's a quick example:

```ts
import * as dateFns from './date-fns-deno/index.js';

const res = dateFns.parseISO('2010-03-14', {});
console.log(res); // 2010-03-14T05:00:00.000Z
```

Also, depending on which date-fns functions you want to use, you might still be able to use the published version on deno.land. You can't bulk-import the whole library for now but can still use the functions that are not missing import statements if you import them individually.

Every module entry point is an `index.js` or `index.ts` file inside a directory that matches the function name. You can conveniently browse the file system structure on the deno site if you need to verify the correct path to use: https://deno.land/x/date_fns@v2.22.1

```ts
import parseISO from 'https://deno.land/x/date_fns@v2.22.1/parseISO/index.js';

const res = parseISO('2010-03-14', {});
console.log(res); // 2010-03-14T05:00:00.000Z
```

@kossnocorp @leshakoss @tan75 Anything else I can do to make this PR go through?

Was there a change of heart in supporting Deno altogether? (last published release was 2.22.1, and it looks like this PR was expected to be merged in 2.23 and 2.24).
Rebased and added some additional fixes to address recent library changes (mostly type and import issues). The PR should be in a mergeable state again.
@tan75 saw that you self-assigned - I'm working on a rebase and fixes following all the things that got merged to master recently. Hold on a bit.

@tan75 OK, we're in a happy place again. It's astounding the amount of type issues that snuck in. The eslint configuration in the project is not adequate at all. This Deno smoke test is catching a lot of things, which is nice. But these errors should surface more naturally with the linter. I might have a look later this week and work on a PR. I think one of the reasons these missing imports are happening is because the `date-fns` project itself has `date-fns` v1 in its deps through lint-staged (pointed out in #2476) and the ambient type defs of v1 are leaking. That seems like such a dangerous setup, this transitive dependency should really be removed.

Another thing, I think it would make sense that the `/scripts/build/deno.sh` script publish to `/tmp/deno` by default instead of `/deno`. That way it would match the `/scripts/build/package.sh` behavior a bit more closely. Maybe it also needs a destination output cli arg.

hi @fturmel 
thanks a lot for all your amazing work that you have put in Deno version but we are currently not sure if we are going to continue supporting it at all as it looks like a lot of extra work involved when it comes to release and support. 

I have self-assigned this as I am going to discuss this with @kossnocorp and @leshakoss again but this will happen in late January. Until then, I am not sure what will happen with the Deno version of date-fns.

@tan75 Thanks, really appreciate the note.

I understand what you're saying. It's an emergent platform (although maybe already stagnating a bit?), and it would be nice for date-fns to be represented, but it's not my call to make.

My counterpoints would be:

- Most (all?) of the work is done already
- The errors caught with this little smoke test I wrote are actual TypeScript type errors, not necessarily Deno-centric so it's helping the overall project's code quality.
- Once the Deno tests run against new PRs, there would be no more catching up to do. Errors would be addressed before they are merged.
- Couldn't the publishing on deno.land be fully automated with github actions, and trigger on new release/tag?

Soft reset and only kept the fixes that address the very few remaining type issues in master.

~Deno tests will still fail until we integrate the `uk` locale type fixes in #2911, so this is back in draft mode~ merged!

body:
## What

Allow the `formatDuration`, to convert overflowing values into its higher units.

`90 seconds` -> `1 minute 30 seconds`
`3024075 seconds` -> `1 month 5 days 1 minute 15 seconds`
Related to #2509, this PR ensures that we use integer value from `Date.getTimezoneOffset()`.

(Sorry for the large amount of files modified here, it's simpler than it looks at first glance.)

This PR is essentially making the build system (fp.js and indices.js) output TypeScript files instead of JS, with a few additional related TypeScript conversions.

Overview:

- required changes to `fp.js` and `indices.js` + adding 'index.ts' and 'test.ts' filenames to a few ignore arrays
- `fp/test.ts` converted to TS
- `fp/_lib/convertToFP` internal function and its test file converted to TS
- the 3 indices generated by `indices.js` are now TS files, no content change (`index.ts`, `fp/index.ts`, `locale/index.ts`)
- 200+ fp index files converted to TS and simplified a bit (all generated by `fp.js` script). It's all the same pattern, so hopefully not too hard to quickly review.

All tests are passing, full build and package steps run fine. I think we should be good. ü§û

body:
Hi,

I've been working with `date-fns`  and I saw that the `add` and `subtract` functions fail when they receive a `Duration` argument that contains one or more params that were set explicitly as `undefined`.

Below is an example
```ts
import { add, sub } from 'date-fns';

const now = new Date();
const tomorrow = add(now, { days: 1, months: undefined }); // Tomorrow is invalid date
const yesterday = sub(now, { days: 1, months: undefined }); // Yesterday is invalid date
```

This happens, because of this check:

```ts
const months = 'months' in duration ? toInteger(duration.months) : 0
```

And since `months` is inside the `duration`, but is not an integer, the function fails.

I've created a PR with a proposed fix and some unit tests to validate that everything is working.

Thanks,
Komyg
comments:
Hi @tan75, could we merge this PR? I am not authorized to do so.

Thanks,
Komyg
commit_messages:
Allow passing undefined in the duration to add and sub (#2515)

Added: Allowed passing `undefined` in the duration to add and sub functions.

body: attempt to implement #2421 . I made it using the floor as roundingMethod default.
attempt to solve #2078 , any suggestions on how should I implement this?
comments:
My 2 cents (caveat: not a maintainer)

I like the idea for these personally, even if it's minor syntactic sugar. I noticed a lot of the internal tests have inlined comments to identify months more easily, so this is one scenario that could see a slight improvement in adopting enums.

ex:
https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/ea3f05069605388af0bb6a27f8cf4539f3d70db6/src/add/test.ts#L22-L25

Some thoughts on implementation:
- I think this should go in the constants file instead of an additional package
- Depending on what it transpiles too, you could probably just make these actual TypeScript enums. They are zero-based auto-incremented integers by default too so even simpler.
- The JSDocs type should be either enum of numbers, or object with string keys and number values
- Unit tests for constant values don't serve any purpose imo, so I would remove that
- Up to debate whether a 3 letter abbreviation could be preferred over the full word for conciseness (`Month.Sep` vs `Month.September`)
- Not in your PR (yet?), but per #2078 should the week day enum be called `DayOfWeek` or simply `Day` to match the internal type already established? I like `DayOfWeek`, but there is a precedent in the codebase to consider.

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/ea3f05069605388af0bb6a27f8cf4539f3d70db6/src/types.ts#L22-L24

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/ea3f05069605388af0bb6a27f8cf4539f3d70db6/src/types.ts#L38-L40

@fturmel thanks for the tips. However, I tried to use typescript enum but I kept receiving this error `typescript Parsing error: Unexpected reserved word 'enum'`.
Then I decided to use the objects of JS.
@fturmel fixed.

I've identified a blocker just now... The build step generates TypeScript and Flow types based on jsdocs. It doesn't know what to do with objects or enums in the constants file, so it will emit broken definitions.

This PR should be on hold until it can address this type generation hurdle, or until the date-fns project finishes its TypeScript migration and uses `tsc` to generate the type definitions per the migration plan #1932

body:
Add a function to clamp a date based on an interval.

This function ensures that a date is bounded by a minimum and maximum
comments: Sorry @tan75, I accidentally closed the PR

@Liam-Tait 
could you please provide any use cases for `clamp`?

> Hi @Liam-Tait
> this function is a great idea and it might be very useful! Thank you for your PR! üëç

Thanks!

> Could you please make the examples consistent with our current example convention - e.g. see this one below:
> [Next Monday example](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/src/nextMonday/index.ts#L18-L21)
> Now the convention is to use `const` and please delete the 'javascript' mention.
> As well, please format the examples and the 'Docs' part of the file - it's good to have them consistent with the `nextMonday` example. Let us know if anything is unclear.

I think I have matched the convention. Let me know if this correct

- use `const` instead of `var`
- removed javascript mention
- removed backtick code section
- inline parameters instead of using seperate variables
- Add comment for the question the function is answering
- Add comment for the returned value

> @Liam-Tait
> could you please provide any use cases for `clamp`?

My use case is for querying a list of data based on a contract. 

The query has a minDate and maxDate
The contract has a start and end
The data has a date 

I only want to retrieve the data within the period of a contract.
In order to do this i want to clamp the query minDate  and max Date to the contract interval.

Ideally this would be done at the database layer, however that option is not available to me.
```javascript
const minDate = clamp(requestedMin, contractInterval)
const maxDate = clamp(requestedMax, contractInterval)
const result = query(minDate, maxDate)
```

---
Useful for when there is an allowed period of time (interval) and a user input of date and instead of causing an error bounding to the allowed range
Updated! Please take a look

Added a new `clamp` function that allows to bound a date to an interval.

comments:
I was curious and logged a few things during the CI tests to figure out what exactly was happening.

`getOperationSystemLocale()` returned 'C' because `process.env.LANG` is 'C.UTF-8' in that environment.

```ts
new Intl.DateTimeFormat('C').format(new Date())
// Uncaught RangeError: Incorrect locale information provided
```

When running `yarn test` locally, the `process.env` object appears to be completely empty so that function returns `undefined`.

```ts
new Intl.DateTimeFormat(undefined).format(new Date())
// "8/27/2021"
```

body: attempt to solve #2324 .

Using ordinal number modifier with dates in Russian is **strongly discouraged** by all authoritative sources:
* http://new.gramota.ru/spravka/letters/87-rubric-99 ([Gramota.ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/–ì—Ä–∞–º–æ—Ç–∞.—Ä—É), the top source for Russian language rules and such): "–ù–∞—Ä–∞—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –Ω–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑—É–µ—Ç—Å—è: [...] –ü—Ä–∏ –∑–∞–ø–∏—Å–∏ –∫–∞–ª–µ–Ω–¥–∞—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö —á–∏—Å–µ–ª: 22 –º–∞—Ä—Ç–∞ 2003 –≥–æ–¥–∞, 1 –∞–ø—Ä–µ–ª—è, 10 —è–Ω–≤–∞—Ä—è. –ù–µ: 22-–≥–æ –º–∞—Ä—Ç–∞ 2003-–≥–æ –≥–æ–¥–∞, 1-–≥–æ –∞–ø—Ä–µ–ª—è, 10-–µ —è–Ω–≤–∞—Ä—è." ("Modifier is not used: [...] When writing calendar numbers: [Examples]".)
* http://www.evartist.narod.ru/text1/31.htm ([Rosental](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietmar_Rosenthal)'s guidebook): "–ù–µ–¥–æ–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–º—ã –Ω–∞—Ä–∞—â–µ–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–∏ –∫–æ–ª–∏—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —á–∏—Å–ª–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö, –æ–±–æ–∑–Ω–∞—á–µ–Ω–∏—è—Ö –¥–∞—Ç, –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ –ø—Ä–∏ —Ä–∏–º—Å–∫–∏—Ö —Ü–∏—Ñ—Ä–∞—Ö: –∏–∑ 25 —É—á–∞—Å—Ç–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤, 24 –º–∞—è, VII —Å—ä–µ–∑–¥." ("Modifiers are not allowed for quantitative numerals, date designations, or Roman numerals: [Examples].")

body:
This PR lowers the error count of the `yarn tsc --noEmit` command from 54 to 16 (all from test.ts files).

14 of the remaining 16 errors are caused by `lint-staged v7`'s dependency tree bringing in `date-fns` itself: `lint-staged -> listr -> listr-verbose-renderer -> date-fns:"^1.27.2"`. The duplicate type definitions clash with the project's `typings.d.ts`. Could that also be potentially dangerous? (ex: accidental wrong import path in a unit test might silently run against an older version of the library)

I can think of two approaches to resolve this, would love to get feedback so I can put together a follow-up PR. I tend to prefer the first one.

1. Bump `lint-staged` to the latest version, which would get rid of that `date-fns` nested dependency altogether
2. Add `skipLibCheck` to `tsconfig.json`. This could be suppressing important type feedback though, see https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig#skipLibCheck
comments:
I thought of a 3rd option this morning, migrating to `pnpm` would resolve these potential phantom dependency problems altogether. https://pnpm.io/motivation#creating-a-non-flat-node_modules-directory

I tested it quickly and not only does it remove these tsc errors, but it surfaced that `tslib` and `@babel/plugin-proposal-class-properties` are currently phantom dependencies in the project. It also pointed out that `babel-eslint` has been deprecated and was moved to `@babel/eslint-parser`.
Going to close this PR, #2901 will cover the same grounds and much more. Also #2899 would get rid of the transitive dep mentioned if merged.

body:
As Deno requires extensions in imports while TypeScript hates them, we have to build Deno separately. This PR incorporates the Deno package into the build and release process.

The Deno package is included as a git submodule (Deno requires a package to be published at GitHub, so here it goes: https://github.com/date-fns/deno) avoid noise in the date-fns repo and simplify building.

What's left:

- [ ] Update and commit Deno before the release
- [ ] Creating a git tag after the release
- [ ] Add README
- [ ] Communicate with the Deno team the change and adjust the Deno Land configuration.
