body:
I never managed to successfully run the `build.sh` script on my machine before, it always completely destroyed my MacBook Air M1 16GB to the point where I had to force quit VS Code. CPU, RAM were pegged and it was swapping like crazy.

After taking a closer look, it looks like the jsdocs to markdown task is spawning 207 node processes at the same time!

Here‚Äôs a proposed fix which simply limits the amount of async tasks to the number of cores on the machine. In my case, I can see that the CPU usage looks optimal without making the computer unresponsive, RAM usage is stable and there is no swapping. The `docs.js` execution actually completes in about 50 seconds.

While editing this file, I also replaced the `fs-promise` package (deprecated) with the native `fs/promises`. It was only used here, so I removed it from the project's dev dependencies.
comments: More supporting evidence of the problem, after over 4 minutes running `build.sh`, my computer is dying and we're not anywhere close to being done with the first step (in fact it never seems to be able to finish and I have to force quit VS Code). With this PR, `build.sh` executes completely in under 53 seconds and memory usage is stable.
Interesting, maybe it's an architecture thing or you have more RAM on that machine. Happy to help.
commit_messages: Fix docs generation perf issue by limiting processes to machine CPU count (#2459)

body: When using `differenceInSeconds`, the value is truncated: 1.9 second become 1 second. However, until a rounding option is introduced, it is more accurate to round the remaining seconds instead of truncating it.
comments:
> why round should be the default rounding method (which we might change in v3)?

Well, my personal use case is to display images from CCTV based on user requested timestamp. Some images might not be exactly at the requested time, so I display the difference between the requested timestamp and the actual image timestamp. When the user requested `2021-04-02 12:42:40.000` and the image is at `2021-04-02 12:42:41.950`, the current implementation will give an interval of one second.

I would much prefer a version with (optionally) milliseconds in the interval, but the result of 1 second is more misleading than 2 seconds: the image is nearer to 2 seconds late than 1 second late.

To be honest‚Ä¶ I totally agree that this is a breaking change. So, I'll try to make a `roundingMethod` parameter as soon as possible with the default using the current behavior (`floor`).

body: This pr fixes: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns-typescriptify/issues/154
comments:
> Great job! Please format using Prettier config, use `import type` where possible, modernize the code, simplify types, and get rid of extra type conversions (`Number()`; of course if it's possible).

Prettier generated extra load for the reviewer)

Just wanted to say that although I like the extra punctuation in German months abbreviations (e.g. "Feb." instead of "Feb.", see https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/src/locale/de/_lib/localize/index.ts#L22), it makes working with different languages in one code base harder because of the inconsistency.
So if you want a date with an abbrivated month, thanks to this PR working with German dates got a whole lot easier: `2021-02-01` becomes "01. Feb. 21" with `dd. MMM yy`, `2021-05-01` on the other hand results in "01. Mai 21", so without a dot. But if you work with English dates as well, it will be "01. Feb 21" and "01. May 21", both without a dot.

body: fixes #2307
comments:
- To format difference in years, months, days we compare like before:
  ```
  var rawDifference = dateRight.getTime() - dateLeft.getTime.getTime()
  var timezoneOffsetDifference = getTimezoneOffsetInMilliseconds(dateRight) - getTimezoneOffsetInMilliseconds(dateLeft)
  var difference = rawDifference - timezoneOffsetDifference
  ```
  The effect of that is that the distance between 12 AM of two consecutive days is always calculated like 24 hours and DST is ignored.
- To format difference in hours, minutes, seconds we compare `dateRight.getTime() - dateLeft.getTime()`.

body:
Functions like differenceInMonths, differenceInDays, ... , which are used in intervalToDuration, expect dateLeft to be the later date and dateRight the earlier date. Currently, intervalToDuration sets its dateLeft to its earlier date and dateRight to its later date. This has been fixed in this PR: by setting dateLeft to the end date and dateRight to the start date.

While the dateLeft and dateRight arguments can normally be switched in these functions, because they work in both cases as they use Math.abs, a sign variable, ..., meaning that it shouldn't matter in what order intervalToDuration passes dateLeft and dateRight to these functions, there are two reasons why I still think this change is useful:
- It's more logical that if the dateLeft is the later date in these 'difference' functions, this is also the case in the intervalToDuration function
- In my case, the intervalToDuration bug with Feb 28th #2255, would not have occurred if dateLeft would have been set as the later date in intervalToDuration
comments: I feel like it's the differenceInX arguments that are named incorrectly, they should be something like `dateMinuend` and `dateSubtrahend`. Or just `laterDate` and `earlierDate`

@leshakoss I agree, using laterDate and earlierDate is more logical. I can adapt the PR if needed. I just tackled it this way because there are many differenceInX functions and I thought that was done on purpose and the error was in the intervalToDuration function.

Typescriptifed subBusinessDays as well https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns-typescriptify/issues/139

addBusinessDays(new Date(), 1, {

body:
This PR aims to solve 2 problems mentioned in https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1273:

1. Use the `"other"` token as default when locale's `formatRelative` does not handle a more specific token (e.g. `"tomorrow"` returns `undefined`) (solution suggested in https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1273#issuecomment-522949806)
2. Improve the error message thrown when `formatStr` passed to `format` is undefined.
    Previously, the error message thrown in such a situation would be `RangeError: Format string contains an unescaped latin alphabet character n`, which does not really say much

The 2nd change is not mentioned specifically in the ticket, but I reckon it would at least help with debugging in some cases, especially when `format` is called internally within some other API function.

This is my first contribution to the project, which I am excited about üôÇ 

## Formatting changes

I have noticed that the formatting in the files I modified differs vastly from what prettier's formatting. I presume this is because of a recent commit that upgrades prettier (https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/commit/4a328dda165320dde149c531d8643c597ce7170f), but does not reformat files.

That confused me a bit and made me spend time on verifying prettier's configuration üòÑ I reckon it would be nice to clearly communicate in `CONTRIBUTING.md` that there may be formatting issues and how to proceed in such cases (reformat the file, or discard formatting changes) üôÇ That could help other contributors

I separated reformatting the files I modified in this PR into separate commits. Hopefully, that makes the functional changes easier to verify

## Rebuilng using `scripts/build/build.sh`

I have tried running `build.sh`, as instructed in `CONTRIBUTING.md`, but it failed:

```sh
‚úò-INT ~/projects/open-source/date-fns [use-default-token-in-formatRelative|‚Ä¶1]
09:17 $ ./scripts/build/build.sh
+ ./scripts/build/docs.js
TypeError: Cannot read property 'customTags' of undefined
    at /home/voreny/projects/open-source/date-fns/scripts/build/docs.js:43:13
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at generateDocsFromSource (/home/voreny/projects/open-source/date-fns/scripts/build/docs.js:41:6)
```

I did not dig deep enough to find out why, as I don't have much knowledge about this build pipeline.

Here are the contents of my `./tmp` directory (inside of the repo):
```sh
09:32 $ ls tmp --all --tree
tmp
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitkeep
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tests_count.txt
```

Let me know what I should do in this case üôÇ

body:
#### New Feature
Implement intlFormatDistance for date-fns
comments:
WIP:
* intlFormatDistanceToNow
* Test Cases

Or... split this implementation to:
- `intlFormatDistanceStrict` which uses `numeric: always` and takes 'ceil', 'round', 'floor' arguments.
-  `intlFormatDistance` which uses `numeric: auto` where applicable and generally rounds the years.

My 2cts would be to avoid providing the exact arguments of `Intl.RelativeTimeFormat` and allow room to algorithmically use the right unit and formatting options.

An other thing to review would be wether outputting 'quarters' by default makes sense to most implementations. Date-fns is slightly opinionated in its other implementations (i.e. when to include time in 'relative' and never returning '4 quarters ago' in formatDistance), providing that as an option to control would make this more useful, otherwise I would find myself going back to first comparing the dates, then calling intlFormatDistance with unit months when I know we're talking about 3-12 months distance.

@tan75 the typescript compiler needs to know that you are using es2020.intl definitions. In .tsconfig you should add es2020 to the target. Also, this is a good case to catch, as older browser will also not know about this constructor and fail.

```ts
const IntlRelativeSupported = typeof Intl.RelativeTimeFormat === 'function';
```

body:
Closes #2161, Related: #1495

To run the test:

    yarn test --browser LocalFirefox

## Context

In #1495 there was a fix to `Math.ceil` timezone offsets. This must have fixed some issues but in this case, the `format` function returns the incorrect format when trying to format a duration due to the rounded-up offset.

I tried `Math.floor` but that made other tests fail. Instead I propose using `Math.trunc` which will chop off any additional digits from the offset which I think will match what Chrome does. There could still be edge cases I'm missing so would like additional feedback.

## Changes

- Add failing test case when run under Firefox 84
- Switch to `Math.trunc` which makes all existing tests pass and the FF test pass

## Open Questions

1. I would guess there's additional configuration needed to run the suites in Sauce Labs Firefox? Can someone help with that (or follow-up in separate PR?)
2. Commit hooks keep formatting the files I touch which mixes in format changes. I know most folks don't like mixing behavior with formatting in PRs, should I keep those changes out like I've been trying?

According to the official Czech language maintainer (https://prirucka.ujc.cas.cz/?id=810), current date-fns short and medium date formats are not allowed. Moreover, officially acknowledged formats are not parsed by date-fns properly.

The changes are as follows:
 - two-digits year is not allowed
 - if there are no spaces after `.` in the date, month and day must be two-digits
 - format with 1-2 digits and a space after `.` is the most common one

Note for the PR: I have run the `./scripts/build/build.sh` command, but it made many (693) formatting changes in js and flow files, which is not intended, I guess.

body:
This PR adds a new option `strict` to [`parse`](https://date-fns.org/v2.16.1/docs/parse) to enforce the same length of the date part in the date string as the length of tokens in the format string.

See #1849
comments:
## Overall test of strict mode

I temporary hardcoded `strict` to `true` to test the strict option with all tests and it performed well, only this test failed

```
it('zero-padding', function() {
    var result = parse('1', 'KK', referenceDate)
    assert.deepEqual(result, new Date(1986, 3 /* Apr */, 4, 1))
})
```

which IMHO shall return `Invalid Date` in strict mode, for format string `KK` requires two digits.

## Regarding EcmaScript version

The source code contains a wide range of ES syntax, from ES5 with keywords `var` and `function` to ES6 with `let`, `const` and fat arrow functions. I choose the modern flavor for tests, as it runs in Node.js or Chrome, and I kept the library code in ES5. I also read the CONTRIBUTION.md and saw a note about migration to TypeScript, but rewriting the parsing code to TypeScript is a much larger project, than adding a strict parse feature. What do you recommend me to do? Use ES6 syntax and rely on babel to transpile it for supported browsers? Write library code in ES5? Or use TypeScript? I'm quite comfortable with TypeScript btw.

I need this - I'm importing data an my clients get confused when a "07" year gets parsed to year 7 and does not throw an error. See my current workaround here: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/942#issuecomment-1565624419

comments: Hey! Could you please explain the rationale behind the change? The day is just the index (of `["Monday", "Tuesday", ...]`), which is by itself confuses a lot of people, introducing the option will only make it worse. So unless there's a specific reason (like it enables integration with the Jalali calendar) and we find a better name for it, I won't be merging it. Sorry!

FYI, This was the original issue that raised this one here
https://github.com/smmoosavi/date-fns-jalali/issues/2

@kossnocorp 
can you remove the `hacktoberfest-accepted` label and merge this pull request? we really need the `weekStartsOn` option in `getDay` function

Sorry, this is not a change we can accept, so I have to close the PR. If you're ready to discuss the problem and come up with an acceptable approach, please [open a discussion](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/discussions/new) and describe the issue in detail with links to the code.

Adding this option to `setDay` was a mistake and will be removed in the next major version.

First of all, the day is a static value and has nothing to do with `weekStartsOn`. Look at it as an array where Sunday is always the first element and Saturday is the last.

Secondly, the day is already a source of confusion as  i.e. `new Date(2021, 1, 1)` represents the 1st of February and not January. Altering it on a locale change is just an unnecessary brain twister.

@kossnocorp So I think we can accept a convention here, where "Saturday" does not mean the start of a week. It's just the first item in an array of week days.  
If we agree on that, don't you think we need a `getWeekDay` method, which returns how many days is passed from first week day?
what about `setDaysSinceWeekStart`?
@smmoosavi sounds good to me!
another suggestion: `getDeyOfWeek` and `setDeyOfWeek`.

body:
To make the diffs a little easier to read I made had one commit that just ran `prettier` on the whole repo.

The next commit adds `prettier` to the `lint` script to enforce styling for all js, ts, and json files.

Prettier now runs on pre-commit hooks not just for js files but for ts and json as well.

Fixes #753
comments: Hey, thank you a lot for the effort, but I can't accept this PR. First of all, it's too much of a burden to review every file, which I must do to ensure no security breaches or other sensitive issues. It's much easier for me to run the Prettier myself. Secondly, it will break multiple PRs and add more work for other contributors and me.

@kossnocorp Totally understandable about not trusting the `prettier --write` commit. The reason I included two separate commits was to make review easier. I'd be happy to pull that commit out and let you run it yourself. The real change aside from running `prettier --write` only changes two lines:

```diff
diff --git a/package.json b/package.json
index f4dd1ff1..839c7cc0 100644
--- a/package.json
+++ b/package.json
@@ -21,7 +21,7 @@
   "module": "esm/index.js",
   "scripts": {
     "test": "karma start config/karma.js",
-    "lint": "eslint .",
+    "lint": "eslint . && prettier --check '**/*.{js,ts,json}'",
     "lint-types": "eslint --config=.ts-eslintrc.js typings.d.ts",
     "locale-snapshots": "env TZ=utc babel-node --extensions .ts,.js ./scripts/build/localeSnapshots/index.js",
     "benchmark": "env TEST_BENCHMARK=true yarn test --single-run",
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
     }
   },
   "lint-staged": {
-    "*.js": [
+    "*.{js,ts,json}": [
       "prettier --write",
       "git add"
     ]
```

That's a great point though about breaking existing PRs. I can't really think of a good way to close #753 without taking a really long time or waiting until you have very few PRs open.

I think at the very least you could add ts and json to the pre-commit hook, which wouldn't break any existing PRs and would format those files going forward. If you're migrating to ts it seems like you'd want to be formatting those files as well.

@kossnocorp I updated this branch to only have the lint-staged change (without running prettier on the whole codebase adding `prettier --check` to `lint` wouldn't make sense since that would break everyone's tests).

I feel like that'd be a safe step towards making progress on #753. If you want I could create a new PR or I think you could just reopen this one for it to sync up.

@redbmk, thank you for understanding. If you don't mind, could you please open another PR with the lint-staged update and re-open this one with the lint command update? I want to push the first one right now, and the second will have to wait. Thanks!

body:
This pull request adds a new `yearStartsOn` option to the following functions:

- startOfQuarter, startOfYear

- endOfQuarter, endOfYear

- isSameQuarter, isSameYear

This new feature allows us to count the start of a year from another month than January. The `yearStartsOn` option is a number that can range from 0 to 11, with 0 representing January and 11 representing December.

It is not uncommon to have businesses that start tracking their yearly reports from another month than January. This functionality would save a lot of converting to and from the fiscal year.

Closes #2014

The functions: getDecade, getHours, getISODay, getISOWeek, getISOWeekYear,
getISOWeeksInYear, getMilliseconds, getMinutes, getMonth, getOverlappingDaysInIntervals,
getQuarter, getSeconds, getTime, getUnixTime and getYear are migrated to TS

body:
I cannot think any context where one would display eg. `Duration: hour` instead of `Duration: 1 hour`. [English seems to be using numerals as well.](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/a91e059dce796c580d54d5894dd9f19348dd86fa/src/locale/en-US/_lib/formatDistance/index.js#L30)

Source: I'm a native speaker.

I hope the CI will run tests for me as I don't have Chrome. Also, could someone run `yarn locale-snapshots` for me as it fails to find `env` on my (Windows) box? Marking the PR as a draft until then.
comments: I do believe it is, at least somewhat, context specific. The `futureTense` in particular seems a bit off: `vuoden kuluttua` changed to `1 vuoden kuluttua` does not sound like an improvement to me ‚Äì on the contrary.

Another native speaker here chiming in. üëã 

While I generally agree with the original patch of adding number `1` to the front of the duration of single units, I'm afraid that the slightly awkward future tense that @Pyppe mentioned is, in fact, an unintended consequence resulting from the automatic conversion. It doesn't sound very good to me either. If we want to have this change anyway, I'm suggesting to change it to something more like in [the attached patch](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/files/5443726/fix-future-distance.txt) to make it a bit less invasive, but I do admit that it makes the code slightly more convoluted. Would be happy to hear comments from @ljani as well.

One could discuss `in a minute` vs `in 1 minute` with English locale as well, but I agree that in Finnish it's more awkward as @Pyppe mentioned.

To be honest, if you ask my opinion, I don't like `vuoden kuluttua` either, and would prefer something like `vuoden p√§√§st√§`. [`kuluttua`](https://fi.wiktionary.org/wiki/kuluttua) refers to "after some event" where as [`p√§√§st√§`](https://fi.wiktionary.org/wiki/p%C3%A4%C3%A4st%C3%A4#Postpositio) is used more like "after some time".

Personally, I'd prefer `minuutti sitten` over `1 minuutti sitten` as well, what do you think? With English, I'd also prefer `a minute ago` over `1 minute ago`.

@juhovh: Your patch looks good to me. Can you make the changes to this PR?
Hi guys! Thanks a lot for your contribution. This seems like a dead PR at this point. Feel free to reopen it with the patch mentioned above.

body: Add function to parse an ISO 8601 duration from a string into the Duration type.
comments:
The main issue with an empty object is if I want to determine if the entered string is not a valid ISO 8601 duration to say display an error message, it is hard to check if the return value is an empty object while it is easy to check for NaN or Invalid Date.

I guess lodash has the isEmpty function which does the check, and I am using lodash so I guess it isn't a big deal, I can use lodash to check for empty object and display an error.

@wuzzeb I understand the issue, but one of the library core values is consistency with ECMAScript. And when the user input is processed, we always get a value of the same type so the code could continue work and output something instead of throwing an exception. Also, as you said, you can either check the result for emptiness (`Object.keys(result).length` will do the trick) or even verify the sum of values (unless you want to allow 0 duration).
Hey, was just looking for this! Any update? Thanks a lot!
Hi, any update about this pull request ?

@wuzzeb are you able to get the requested changes in? We just hit this and are temporarily using your code directly. I don't want to step on any toes, but am raising my hand üôã in case I can assist in getting this across the finish line. Thanks for getting this started!
@benjamincharity, feel free to finish this. I would also love to hear your thoughts about `null` vs. `{}` as you have a use case for the function. Appreciate it!

Just to add my own ¬£0.02, I agree with returning `{}` rather than `null` for invalid input. In my mind, the most semantic API would be either:
* return `{}` (caller is guaranteed to receive the same return type regardless of input as @kossnocorp suggested, a la `new Date('garbage')`); or
* throw `Error` (caller is explicitly forced to handle the exception thrown from attempting to set an invalid Duration, a la `JSON.parse('garbage')`)
 
However, `throw` feels a little nuclear to me, for something that's essentially a nice-to-have utility.

@kossnocorp I definitely understand wanting `null` for an easy check by the consumer; but also realize the value of a consistent API. In this case I would defer to members of this org.

I have pulled in the commits from @wuzzeb and addressed the comments above in the new PR here: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/2302
Thanks, @wuzzeb for the initial development, @benjamincharity continued the PR there: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/2302#
Third attempt at getting this in! https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/3151
Would love this feature.

body:
[ts-migrate](https://github.com/airbnb/ts-migrate/tree/master/packages/ts-migrate) is a CLI tool from Airbnb to help migrate large codebases from JS to TypeScript all in once. 

It runs codemod helpers with a single purpose - to transform JS into compilable TypeScript. It is not ideal, does not guesses all the types correctly, but serves as a good migration starter from JS to TS.

[More on ts-migrate](https://medium.com/airbnb-engineering/ts-migrate-a-tool-for-migrating-to-typescript-at-scale-cd23bfeb5cc).

This PR is an experiment and is WIP, mostly to check if ts-migrate can be used as a migration strategy inline with [Migrate to TypeScript](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/discussions/1932) discussion.

Status
- [x] /src/* transformed
- [x] `yarn test` runs succesfully
- [ ] fix `yarn benchmark`
- [x] fix `./scripts/build/build.sh`
- [x] fix `./scripts/build/package.sh`

Renaming is a separate commit, for an easier audit of transformations.
comments: @kossnocorp yeah, no problem. This PR wasn't meant to be merge at all. Was just experimenting with ts-migrate. It worked pretty good, lol.
@opudalo awesome, looking forward!

@kossnocorp I've reverted all transformations/file renaming. 
But this won't compile right now (tests, build scripts won't pass). 
Instead of trying to make Schrodinger tsification (merge only builder parts and support both TS/JS states) I suggest you to take over this PR and finish it. I've added helper scripts so you can migrate code yourself. 

Proposed todo:

1. `yarn ts-migrate:rename-all` Will rename .js ‚Üí .ts files in `src/*` directory. `ts-migrate` has no way to specify directory to apply renaming, so it does `./*` and then its manually removes renames except in `src` and reverts to git state (run and you'll see)
2. `yarn ts-migrate:migrate` will migrate all files in `src/*` to TypeScript. It mostly adds "@ts-expect-error", so it will compile, but it is not "true" migration.
3. fix `yarn benchmark`. For some reason it won't work for me in master too.
4. review everything and marge to master PR with both builder and applied transformations together.

Let me know if I can help with any, but this should be straightforward. As its major change, also it would make sense to create manual test checklist to double check everything. I can't help creating it, as I'm not that aware in lib internals, so that's on you.
However, I can help with testing stuff.
Amazing, the plans sound great! I'm on it!

@opudalo I finally got to tinkering with the PR. I'm not sure if I want to merge the current result of `ts-migrate` as it doesn't do anything except adding `@ts-ignore`. Right now the migration is easy to track (if it's `.js`, we should migrate it), but with all files named `.ts` it would be more challenging.

I tried to apply [recently added JSDoc plugin](https://github.com/airbnb/ts-migrate/pull/43) but couldn't make it do anything at all. With the result of the plugin, it would be much more valuable.

Could you please try to help me make it work? Here's my script that I experimented with: https://gist.github.com/kossnocorp/9afa7e3cad0e1f5966fc985dde16fed2 (the plugin still not released, so I downloaded the source code locally).

I'm rolling back the transformations and rename for clean diff.

@kossnocorp, guys published a new version and it has jsdoc plugin.

However, we have another problem. In most files params are prefixed with "dirty". Thus, have to a) fix naming in codebase and align jsdoc `@params` and function arg names or b) tweak jsdoc plugin to make it handle "dirty" prefix in the name. It's a hack but it will work. 

What do you think? 

Also, the community is very active in typescriptifying stuff ‚Äì¬†lots of PRs ready to be merged, so maybe we don't need this one at all, which is fine too. :)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/775750/94374359-7347ef80-0114-11eb-9352-f7594a151b29.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/775750/94374328-282ddc80-0114-11eb-875b-32ed8ef09f1d.png)
Closing this because the library is nearly completely typescriptified now

body:
After a failed attempt to migrate the whole library to TypeScript at once (https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/1813), I'm opting to gradual migration.

It will take some time before we will rewrite the whole library into TypeScript, and we'll be able to benefit from it. However, it's much more manageable and won't turn into a neverending release like v2 was.

body:
Fixes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1911. This PR floors the `hourOffset` in `formatRFC3339`, so for non-standard time zones, e.g. for IST, it becomes `05:30` instead of `5.5:30`.

This fix is similar to https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/1599, with the addition of the `formatRFC3339` test to the `scripts/test/formatISO.sh`. If the name of the file needs to be changed, e.g. to `format.sh` (since it now contains both formatISO and formatRFC3339), please let me know!

body:
This PR changes all instances of the Hebrew word "◊ë◊¢◊®◊ö" to the prefix "◊õ" which has the exact same meaning, is much shorter, and actually sounds a little better to native Hebrew speakers (I polled around with my friends and family, obviously this is a subjective statement but I think it's not a harmful assumption).

I checked on the [unicode charts](https://unicode-org.github.io/cldr-staging/charts/37/summary/he.html) and there is no translation of the word "about" anywhere,
and here is an article from the Hebrew Academy (which in Israel holds the mandate for regulating the Hebrew language) which states that bove "◊ë◊¢◊®◊ö" and "◊õ-" can be used interchangeably: https://hebrew-academy.org.il/2020/05/27/%D7%91%D7%A2%D7%A8%D7%9A-%D7%9B%D6%BE/

body:
‚Ä¶with minutes (e.g. India, Australia).

First of all, thanks for making such a modular library! Once we found the issue, we could fix it in minutes in production by forking single-function :)

* Affected time-zones: 
  * Australia, 
  * East of Canada, 
  * India and Sri Lanka, 
  * Islands near by New Zealand
  * I think India is the most populated affected timezone
* Caused formatting offset in expression like `+5.5:30` instead `+05:30`) which makes invalid date in `parseISO()`
* It was simple mistake in division (`-330/60` caused `5.5` hours offset instead full hour)
* I used `toInteger` as it already have condition for positive and negative offset, using `Math.floot()` or `Math.ceil()`. I see in some other functions
* Add specs for interesting and regular timezones for this use case
commit_messages:
Fix `formatRFC3339` formatting timezone offset with minutes (e.g. India, Australia) (#1890)

‚Ä¶with minutes (e.g. India, Australia).

First of all, thanks for making such a modular library! Once we found the issue, we could fix it in minutes in production by forking single-function :)

* Affected time-zones: 
  * Australia, 
  * East of Canada, 
  * India and Sri Lanka, 
  * Islands near by New Zealand
  * I think India is the most populated affected timezone
* Caused formatting offset in expression like `+5.5:30` instead `+05:30`) which makes invalid date in `parseISO()`
* It was simple mistake in division (`-330/60` caused `5.5` hours offset instead full hour)
* I used `toInteger` as it already have condition for positive and negative offset, using `Math.floot()` or `Math.ceil()`. I see in some other functions
* Add specs for interesting and regular timezones for this use case

comments:
> Hey! Thank you for your contribution, could you please tell me how do you plan to use this feature (with a code example). I find the current API is confusing. When I see the nth day of the month, I expect it to give me the nth day, not nth day of the nth week. Do you know the problem?
> 
> I also not sure about edge handling, but to come up with a clear solution first, I should understand what's the real-world use-case for this function.
> 
> Thanks!

Hey @kossnocorp, the problem API is trying to solve is pretty simple. **Try to find the nth weekday of the month**. 

 Eg: If you want the 2nd Sunday of  July 2020, this API will return the date you request. 

```js
getNthDayOfMonth(
new Date(2020, 6, 25),  // pass any date of the month you wanna find nth weekday
0,  // Sunday; Days in Datefns 0 - 6 integers
2  // 2nd Sunday
)
```
Output: 
`Wed Jul 12 2020`

The API will return a date, which is 2nd Sunday of the month. In this case July 12th, 2020. 

Usecase:
It will be useful for churches and events that meet up every nth week of a particular day in a month. So this API will return the date of the event.  

The API params made sense for me and it was based on your comment on issue #780. I have attached the comment here.

The name of the API nthDayOfMonth was based on your [comment](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/780#issuecomment-428898492) on the feature request. Believe nth**Week**dayOfMonth would be an option to be more clear. Lmk what you think. 

https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/780#issuecomment-428898492
@kossnocorp @leshakoss Gentle reminder

Thanks for the work getting it to this stage

Any update on this?
Are there plans to get this merged? Trying to do something similar.

- Incorrect pluralization for ‚Äùvecka‚Äù (should be ‚Äùveckor‚Äù).
- Abbreviations of month names to follow recommendation from Spr√•kr√•det (Svenska skrivregler, 2017).
- Abbreviations of day names to follow same convention as for month names.
- Abbreviations of am/pm (_f√∂rmiddag_/_eftermiddag_) now follow recommendation from Spr√•kr√•det (Svenska skrivregler, 2017) ‚Äì¬†i.e. having a period at the end of ‚Äùfm.‚Äù and ‚Äùem.‚Äù and not e.g. ‚Äùf.m.‚Äù or ‚Äùfm‚Äù.

body:
In the dutch language, abbreviating a month does not require to put a period ``.`` at the end, it's merely optional (and old fashioned).
Adding a period is easier than removing it from the format result.

https://onzetaal.nl/taaladvies/afkortingen-dagen-en-maanden/
comments:
I'm üëé on this change. The basic rule in Dutch is that abbreviations are indicated with the trailing dot, and it should always be used as such to avoid confusion, an example that `date-fns` should also handle correctly is:
> Jan begint school weer. (John starts school again)

Which is an entirely different sentence than:

> Jan. begint school weer. (School starts again in January)

https://www.taaltelefoon.be/maanden-afkorting is more explicit on why and how it is allowed to leave the dot out, translated:
> In certain contexts, like in agendas or on calendars, the dot is often left out. This is also correct.

CLDR actually [supports this notion via standalone vs. formatted use](http://cldr.unicode.org/translation/date-time-1/date-time-patterns#TOC-When-to-use-Standalone-vs.-Formatting), but [uses the dot in both](https://unicode-org.github.io/cldr-staging/charts/37/summary/nl.html#360c210ad4f23085). One could argue that standalone should drop the dot, but that would imho have to start with the CLDR, and this library could then follow.

https://taaladvies.net/taal/advies/vraag/1727 is also explicit btw for the same reasons as the Belgian site:
> Jan/jan., feb/feb. enzovoort zijn 'echte' afkortingen. Dat wil zeggen dat jan niet wordt uitgesproken als 'jan', maar als 'januari', dus als het volledige woord waar de afkorting voor staat. Echte afkortingen worden doorgaans met een punt geschreven, bijvoorbeeld: afb. (afbeelding), sgt. (sergeant), zgn. (zogenaamd). Dat leidt tot jan., feb. of febr., mrt., apr., jun., jul., aug., sep. of sept., okt., nov. en dec. ‚Äì met punt dus.
>
>De schrijfwijze zonder punt is echter ook juist. In lijsten, tabellen, agenda's en dergelijke wordt de punt meestal weggelaten: jan, feb, enzovoort.

This also boils down to: correct is with a dot, without is commonly accepted and also correct, but mostly used like that in tables, lists and agendas and the like.

Note to outsiders: TaalAdvies is the official site of TaalUnie, the main advisory organization tracking evolution of the Dutch language and primary consultants on documenting the "official Dutch language".
I agree with @curry684 on this. I'm not a fan of this change either.

@curry684 @stefanvermaas thank you so much for the input!

@dakkafex if you badly need it, I recommend making a custom locale that depends on `nl` and using it.

body:
Anytime two tokens exist in a format string that have the same priority one needs to take precedent over the other when parsing otherwise incorrect values will be parsed. 

The example that is shown in the snapshots that are now fixed are cases where  E and d coexist such as PPPP. Before some locales would handle it find because E would come before d, but in locales where d came before E there were issues. So adding a sub priority so we can correctly sort which token takes precedent.

en-US : PPPP `'EEEE, MMMM do, y`
ja : PPPP `yÂπ¥MÊúàdÊó•EEEE`

body:
Fixes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1748. This PR adds additional validation when a datetime string is split using the existing RegEx in `splitDateString`, hence `parseISO` will return "Invalid Date" for strings with space(s).

## Current

```js
// Since we only check first 2 array elements, it won't resolve to "Invalid Date".
splitDateString('2014-02-11T07:00:00  basketball'); // ['2014-02-11', '07:00:00', 'basketball']
parseISO('2014-02-1107:00:00  basketball'); // 2014-02-11T00:00:00.000Z (I'm in GMT+7)

// This is also the same for date-only string.
splitDateString('2014-02-11  basketball'); // ['2014-02-11', '', 'basketball']
parseISO('2014-02-11  basketball'); // 2014-02-10T17:00:00.000Z (if time is not specified, we use 12am)
```

## This PR

With that, the solution of this PR is to always check the resulting array length from `splitDateString`. If the array length is more than 2, then it contains space(s) and it should resolve to "Invalid Date".

This is also considering the fact that ISO8601-formatted dates don't have spaces in it (source: https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime).

```js
splitDateString('2014-02-11T07:00:00  basketball'); // ['2014-02-11', '07:00:00', 'basketball']
parseISO('2014-02-11T07:00:00  basketball'); // Invalid Date

splitDateString('2014-02-11  basketball'); // ['2014-02-11', '', 'basketball']
parseISO('2014-02-11  basketball'); // Invalid Date
```

Signed-off-by: Try Ajitiono <ballinst@gmail.com>

Other than the change highlighted by @vin-car , my PR also introduced an additional change: only using "prossimo/scorso" ("next/past") if the relative day is far enough in time, not part of the current week.

I actually investigated a bit better and found out that the "Accademia della Crusca" (sort of a research institute for the Italian language) is [suggesting differently](https://accademiadellacrusca.it/it/consulenza/prossimo-con-unit%C3%A0-temporali/132): "prossimo/scorso" ("next/past") should be always used, no matter if the day is in the current week or not.

I personally never heard someone using e.g. "gioved√¨ prossimo" ("next thursday") to refer to the day after if today is "mercoled√¨" ("wednesday") ü§î 
But if you think it is better, I will undo that part of the changes and only leave the smaller gender change. What do you think?

body:
This PR fixes #1682. Changes are fairly straightforward:
* `add` now only calls `addMonths` if `months` or `years` adding is requested, and it only calls `addDays` if `days` or `weeks` adding is requested. This fixes #1682 by preventing calls to `Date.setXXX` in cases where those calls aren't needed, which in turn prevents mutation of the time from DST end to one hour before DST end. See https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1682#issuecomment-625062812
* `addMonths` and `addDays` now return early if `amount` of increment is zero. This prevents the same problem as #1682 but when calling `addMonths` or `addDays` directly. 
* Re-worked `addMonths` logic to avoid problems like #1758 which are caused by mixing UTC and local-time APIs.
* Added DST tests to `add`, `addMonths`, and `addDays` to verify the fixes above.
* Updated changelog

body:
As documented in #1750, date-fns 2.12 (specifically #1630) contained a breaking change that made `differenceInDays` stop matching `addDays` across a DST boundary.  This PR replaces #1630 with an implementation that fixes #533 (like #1630 did) without causing #1750 (like #1630 also did).

This PR: 
* Fixes #1750 by restoring the 2.11 implementation of `differenceInDays` (so should code-review against 2.11 implementation) but modifying it to fix #533 without triggering #1750. It does this by replacing the use in `differenceInDays` of `compareAsc` with a new local function (`compareLocalAsc`) that compares using local time not UTC timestamps. This change prevents errors when one of the times is on a DST boundary or contains an ambiguous local time due to DST.
* Adds new DST tests for `differenceInDays` to validate the work above. These tests will work in any timezone, thanks to new shared test code that detects DST start in the local timezone. All DST tests in this PR are relative to the DST start/end dates detected for the current timezone. These tests will be skipped in non-DST time zones. 
* Validates that all tests run OK in the America/Los_Angeles, America/Sao_Paulo, Australia/Sydney, and Europe/London timezones. This was done by temporarily adding a TZ env to the `yarn test` script command and then manually running tests under each TZ.
* Adds new JSDoc content and samples for `differenceInDays` to document DST behavior and to explain how to get non-DST behavior (full 24-hour periods only) using `Math.floor(differenceInHours(dateLeft, dateRight)/24)|0`.
* Adds analogous JSDoc content to `differenceInWeeks` which is implemented using `differenceInDays` and shares its DST behavior.
* Updates the changelog with a new empty release section as requested in CONTRIBUTING.md,

**Fix Details**

#533, like most JS bugs related to DST, happened because the pre-2.12 implementation of `differenceInDays` mixed UTC and local date calculations: `CompareAsc` uses UTC comparisons while `Date.setDate` (used in `differenceInDays`) uses local timezone math. The result: on or around DST boundaries `CompareAsc` returned results which suggested that the difference was not a full day when it really was, or vice versa. This led to off-by-one errors in results like #533.

The fix was to restore the 2.11 implementation of `differenceInDays` (effectively reverting #1630) and simply replace usage of `compareAsc` with a new local function `compareLocalAsc` that uses local date math instead.

If you really want to get into the weeds to understand how `setDate` works and why #533 happened, start here: 
* https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-date.prototype.setdate
* https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-local-time-zone-adjustment

**Discussion**

_"Full Days": 24-hour periods vs. matching local times_ 

Some contributors in #533 suggested that date diffs should be measured in 24-hour periods only and should ignore DST.  To see why this is problematic, imagine a user measures a 7-day period from (local) noon to (local) noon one week later.  If we only diff 24-hour periods, then that period would measure 7 days most of the year, but would return 6 days if DST started in the middle.  This intermittent variation is a certain cause of hard-to-diagnose bugs, and is also different from how date-fns has behaved for a long time.  That's why this PR goes back to the 2.11 behavior of taking DST into account.  BTW, if a developer wants to ignore DST and just count 24-hour periods, this PR documents one way (`Math.floor(differenceInHours(dateLeft, dateRight)/24)|0`) in user-visible JSDoc comments.

_API Consistency_

I admit that I couldn't fully understand the consistency discussion in #533. To me it seems like the pre-2.12 behavior was *more* consistent, because in 2.11 `differenceInDays` was consistent with `addDays`, and `differenceInDays` was also consistent with `differenceInMonths`.  And with JS Date APIs like `Date.setDate`.

_Guidelines_

In case it's helpful, here are three general rules of thumb that I use for safe date math:
* For adding/subtracting/comparing hours (and smaller) units, convert to UTC and do all math in UTC.
* For adding/subtracting/comparing days (and larger) units, only use local timezone math, not UTC (unless UTC is the local timezone!) because users expect that day and larger APIs return the same results whether or not a DST transition happened.  Here's a discussion about the same topic in moment.js: https://github.com/moment/moment/issues/78#issuecomment-2979637
* Know which APIs use local vs. UTC math, and don't mix them unless you really, really know what you're doing. When you mix UTC APIs like `Date.getTime` with local APIs like `Date.setDate`, it's easy to end up with off-by-one-hour bugs like #533 or #1083 1510.

**Future Investigation Needed**

TODO: I suspect that `differenceInMonths`, `differenceInISOWeekYears`, and `differenceInYears` are vulnerable to the same bug but I didn't have the time yet to investigate but I wanted to get this breaking-change fix out ASAP.
comments:
My new tests failed in CI for the Atlantic/Azores timezone. Interestingly, the tests failed for `differenceInCalendarDays` whose implementation didn't change in this PR, so either my tests are bad or there's a DST problem with `differenceInCalendarDays`.  I can repro this failure locally and I'll investigate and push a fix, probably tomorrow.  

Luckily the DST config for Atlantic/Azores is unusual: their standard time is UTC-1 and their DST is UTC, so the problem case seems pretty obvious: transitions to or from DST across or on local date boundaries and/or UTC date boundaries.

Kudos to the date-fns team for a great CI setup to catch weird bugs like this!
Thank you so much for detailed research, your help is invaluable üëè

OK, fixed the problem with Atlantic/Azores. The culprit was my test code to find DST boundaries, which broke if those boundaries were at midnight. Fixed now.  Also I rebased to the current master and put my changelog edits on top. 

Should be ready to merge.
I've shipped the change with `date-fns@2.13.0`, thank you again!

body:
_EDIT: Oops, my optimization may have a flaw: if the last day of the new month is a DST transition, then the time on that day may be reset to avoid the "dead hour" or "ambiguous hour" caused by the DST transition. Then, when the date is set to the actual day-of-month, the time needs to be put back to what it was originally. Anyway, I'm marking this PR as a work-in-progress until I can add more tests to capture this case, and to fix it if tests fail. This might mean that this optimization isn't really helpful and I'll close the PR if so._

While investigating #1510 I spent some time optimizing `addMonths`. This PR: 

* Simplifies the code to make it more readable
* Removes the dependency on `getDaysInMonth`
* Removes several lines of code and multiple Date method calls.
* Removes creation of an extra `Date` object
* The changes above doubled the speed of this method (according to `yarn benchmark`) from 526410 ops/sec to 1048890 ops/sec on my 2015 MacBook Pro.

All tests continue to pass.  I also added two passing test cases to ensure that `addMonths` works properly across a DST-start and DST-end boundary.

body:
Add `formatDuration` function that allows formatting [`Duration`](https://date-fns.org/docs/Duration) object as a human-readable string, i.e.:

```js
formatDuration({ years: 0, months: 9 })
//=> '9 months'

formatDuration({ years: 0, months: 9 }, null, { zero: true })
//=> '0 years 9 months'

formatDuration({ years: 2, months: 9, weeks: 3 }, { delimiter: ', ' })
//=> '2 years, 9 months, 3 weeks'
```

A big part of this pull-request is adding weeks to locale's `formatDistance`. Meaning we have to update every locale before we can ship this PR üò±

body:
As reported in the bug report, `differenceInYears` does not work as expected when dealing with a left hand date which is a leap day.

Consider the following:
```
const result = differenceInYears(new Date(2024, 1, 29), new Date(2005, 02, 01));
```
This would have returned the result of `19`. This is incorrect and should be `18`. The reason for this is the following:
```
// Line 36
dateLeft.setFullYear(dateLeft.getFullYear() - sign * difference)
```
In this instance, if the `sign * difference` end up reassigning the date to a non-leap year i.e. 2023, then internally the date is advanced to `1st March 2023`. While this is the default behaviour of the spec for this utility it is creating invalid results.

The setting of the year was only meant to align the two dates to the same year, so the rest of the date could be compared to see if it fell within a full year. To work around this I'm proposing we assign BOTH dates to a leap year to prevent any incorrect date reassignment.

body: This PR resolves issue #1508
comments:
The naming, terminology and use of 'subtraction' here isn't sensible, personally.

The type of the function is `subtractFromIntervals(dates: [DateRange],  operand: DateRange) => [DateRange, ...]`... that is so strange to read.

My understanding from the #1508 description is that this isn't a subtraction,  but better phrased as a "cut out of" or "cut and splice".

I'd also change the type of the function to strictly be:

```
spliceInterval(range: DateRange,  operand: DateRange) => [DateRange, DateRange]
```

Instead of a reduction over an input array; only operate over 1 input.  If users want to reduce an array of date ranges,  they can do that themselves.

IMHO.
@dcousens Nice! I already fixed

Hey! Thank you a lot for your work. However, I've intentionally skipped milliseconds as they aren't present in the [ISO 8601 durations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Durations). You probably have some use case in mind, which is crucial for you, but I prefer to stick to the standard and find another solution to your problem. So, please describe the issue you're trying to solve with this PR. Thanks!
It's been a while, but I remember correctly, the use case was simple. I wanted to be able to add milliseconds to a date.
Then I believe `addMilliseconds` would suffice.
Correct, but if I want to add other parts as well, it would require a call to `.add()` and then to `.addMilliseconds()`.
@BehindTheMath maybe but that's an imaginary case and we prioritize sticking to standards.

I just got "bit" by this as well, when migrating older code. It was kind of a surprise to me that `set` supports `milliseconds` in its option but `add`/`sub` don't. It's the same use case as described by @BehindTheMath where there were multiple nested `addX` calls and which I wanted to convert into a sole `add` call, given that welcome new feature.
@mathieumg I'm sorry about that, but adding this functionality will not only break compatibility with ISO 8601 but also add a huge chunk of work for I18n teams.
@kossnocorp that's an acceptable answer,  but,  let's `if ('milliseconds' in duration) throw TypeError` then?

> type ExtendedDuration = Duration & { milliseconds?: number }

This is the best approach.   I don't think anyone was asking you to change the ISO8601 `Duration` object to include `milliseconds`,  merely,  the functions `add` and `sub` should be more-or-less relative equivalents of `set`.

Sorry in the delay answering!

> However, we might introduce another type with more values and accept it in `add` / `sub`:
> 
> ```
> type ExtendedDuration = Duration & { milliseconds?: number }
> ```

I think that's suitable, as @dcousens mentioned if we can get the convenience in the utility, that's good with me, no need to tamper with ISO specs. :)

> @mathieumg now I'm wondering, did you used milliseconds field and only later figured out that it doesn't work or you got it right away?

Right away, thanks to TypeScript, but I had already migrated the whole line (with nested `addX` calls) and was wondering whether it was a missing typing since it worked for `set`. So, more of an expectation/uniformity thing. (that's when I went to look at the implementation, and also found this issue)

> Another issue is that `set` accepts date values e.g., year, month, etc. while `add` accepts duration year**s**, month**s**. Was it a problem?

Not really a problem, I guess in the end both output a set `Date` at a specific moment so you could want to have a date at a specific number of milliseconds, but you could also want to add/subtract a specific number of milliseconds to an existing date.

I'm happy to make changes where necessary,  this was simply the simplest solution for the primitives.
comments:
For reference,  **BEFORE THIS PATCH**  the `differenceInDays` function returned **different** results depending on your timezone.


Please note,  I have used ISO-8601 timestamps to avoid ambiguity.

``` js
const { differenceInDays } = require('date-fns')

const a = new Date('2019-10-05T15:00:00.000Z') // for TZ=Australia/Sydney, this is 1 hour before DST
const b = new Date('2019-10-06T14:00:00.000Z') // for TZ=Australia/Sydney, this is 1 day  after DST
const c = new Date('2019-10-07T14:00:00.000Z') // for TZ=Australia/Sydney, this is 2 days after DST

console.log(differenceInDays(c, b)) 
console.log(differenceInDays(b, a))
console.log(differenceInDays(c, a))
```

**NOTE**: These results are from __before__ this patch.

For `TZ=Australia/Sydney`
``` js
1
1
2
```

For `TZ=UTC`
``` js
1
0
1
```
@kossnocorp anything I need to do to help this?

> Would be cool if you can add a bit info about the case fixed in this PR to the function description?

What about
```
This function returns the difference in days as an integer whole number of 24 hour periods between two timestamps,  and thereby ignores DST changes.
```
@dcousens sounds logical to me

body:
Fixes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1575. 

Currently, the typing in `isValid`'s function documentation expects a parameter of type `any`. This might lead to confusion as users might think they could pass anything into it.

This PR updates the parameter documentation from `*` to `Date | Number`. This is aimed to ensure let users know what parameter is actually expected by the function.

Signed-off-by: Try Ajitiono <ballinst@gmail.com>
comments:
The purpose of this PR seems to contradict with what we have in the tests, it seems:

```
Cannot call isValid with null bound to date because:
 ‚Ä¢ Either null [1] is incompatible with Date [2].
 ‚Ä¢ Or null [1] is incompatible with number [3].

it('treats null as an invalid date', function() {
  var result = isValid(null)
  assert(result === false)
})
```

Either we remove that test, or we label the issue as "won't fix".

1. If we remove the test, then we fully commit to the idea that `isValid` only accepts a `Date` or `Number`. (looks like more to compile time approach)
2. If we don't, then we keep it as it is -- making the scope of `isValid` as broad as possible for its users to check whether "something" is a valid Date or not. (seems like a runtime approach)

WDYT @kossnocorp?

body:
Just wanted to align Czech and Slovak "short" and "medium" formats with the rest.
My understanding of types:

- *Short*: expecting date with full year
- *Medium*: expecting date with some form of month name
- *Long*: date with full month name
- *Full*: wee day full name, date with full month name

If we can keep formats somehow aligned then switching between locales won't be such pain...
comments: Closing this PR as incorrect.

body:
This pull request removes the ¬∫ symbol from the ordinalNumber formatting function since it's primarily used to indicate the first day of the month. But leaving it away completely is also considered correct and much more common.

Example:
```js
formatDate(new Date(2020, 1, 14), "do MMMM y", itLocale)
// before 14¬∫ febbraio 2020
// after 14 febbraio 2020

```

More infos can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_Italy

Relevant section:
```
The expanded form is "22 dicembre 2010", optionally with the day of the week: "mercoled√¨ 22 dicembre 2010".[1]

The first day of the month is usually written 1¬∫ dicembre or 1¬∞ dicembre; 1 dicembre is also considered correct. The other days of the month follow the usual cardinal form.
```
comments:
hi @date-fns/i18n-it 
could you please have a look into it? Is this a correct approach?
Yes, using the "¬∞" for ordinal dates is quite uncommon, it has sense mostly for the first day of the month.
Hope it's alright, I rebased and updated the snapshot.md file to make it easier to review and merge.

Also, I can do one PR for all the `isBefore` variations and another one for the `isAfter` variations if that makes it easier to review (or even one per function if you prefer). Let me know üëç

comments: Anybody ?

When I do these operations myself,  I think the verbosity increases readability.
For example
``` js
isBefore(startOfDay(a), startOfDay(b))
```

I don't think `isBeforeDay` is easier to read than ^.

The only scenario where `isBeforeDay` is different to `isBefore` is when the day is the same,  but,  if I'm worried about that,  I'd use:

``` js
differenceInCalendarDays(a, b) < 0
```

Granted,  understanding _that_ is harder than what you proposed.
So maybe `isBeforeCalendarDay` is better?  :man_shrugging:

> So maybe `isBeforeCalendarDay` is better? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇ

The idea is to have `isBeforeHour`, `isBeforeWeek`, ..., as well. That's why @kossnocorp suggested that name I guess. `isBeforeCalendarMinute` wouldn't be very good. That said, I'm pretty open to whatever naming.

body:
Currently in flow, `Function` is an alias to `any` and will be deprecated and removed in a future version of Flow:

https://flow.org/en/docs/types/functions/#toc-function-type

This PR replaces all `Function` args in typings with a generic function type `(...args: Array<any>) => any`. We'll replace those with correct types down the line, but at the moment there's no harm in getting rid of a deprecated alias.

Implement the `add(Object)` function from [Moment](https://momentjs.com/docs/#/manipulating/add/) and fix #1427 

> Add 2 hours, 15 minutes and 30 seconds to 10 July 2014 12:45:00;
```
var result = add(new Date(2014, 6, 10, 12, 45, 0), { minutes: 15, hours: 2, seconds: 30 });
```
> result: Thu Jul 10 2014 15:00:30

Supports adding 
```
{
    hours: number,
    years: number,
    days: number,
    quarters: number,
    weeks: number,
    months: number,
    minutes: number,
    seconds: number
} 
```
combined in a single call

body:
Here's one thing to think about though.. JS Date does not allow to have fractional milliseconds. So, the way i've implemented it is that extra digits are simply truncated. E.g.:

2019-12-31T23:59:59.999999Z becomes 2019-12-31T23:59:59.999Z

The question arises: do we need implemented a proper rounding here instead of truncation? E.g., with proper rounding:

2019-12-31T23:59:59.999999Z becomes 2020-01-01T00:00:00Z

In my opinion, this is not really needed and we should keep truncating it for the sake of simplicity. But I'd like to hear different opinions.

This is my first pull request to date-fns library. I have followed the i18n guidelines in [i18nContributionGuide.md](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/docs/i18nContributionGuide.md) and [contribution guide](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md). body:
The ISO date parsing previously done in `toDate` was moved into `parseISO` to keep the minimal build size low when string date manipulation is not required (#1016). The problem is that any application that retrieves a date from an API will parse some form of serialized date string before passing it to other functions. The following is typical example:

```js
const output = format(addDays(parseISO(dateFromAPI), 1), 'yyyy-MM-dd')
```

As soon as `parseISO` is used in this way the benefit of removing `toDate` has been negated. The `parseISO` and `parse` functions are still around 7000 and 8000 bytes respectively. The proposed `parseUTC` function is only ~520 bytes in size and sufficient to parse the standard JSON serialized date string formats of most server-side languages. 

Aside from complete ISO dates and the input types accepted by `toDate` the function returns an `Invalid Date`. The intention of this function will not be to parse user input, for this `parse` would still be needed, but it permits convenient parsing of date strings from an API with a known ISO format.

This is a proposed compromise/solution for the issue I raised [here](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1016#issuecomment-498315179), and something I have used in a couple of projects recently to good effect. 

I am still undecided about the best name for this function. My initial thought was `parseJSONDate`, but then I realized only UTC dates are supported and calling it `parseUTC` might be more generic and describe the function more specifically.

I would like to propose this function for inclusion in the core `date-fns` library, however, if it is deemed not a good fit I can also add it to `date-fns-tz`.
commit_messages:
Add parseJSON function (#1463)

Add `parseJSON` - minimal implementation for parsing dates formatted with `toJSON`.

body:
Parsing data had a mismatch in narrow month format, causing all short format (`PP`, `MMM`, `LLL`) months to fail parsing (it was labeled `short`, which is not used in the parser for month formats).

Also, the method of parsing numbers from the end of the string instead of beginning was causing the parser to read the first number of the year instead of the month, causing incorrect month results on wide format. I took the liberty to conform all the patterns to search at the beginning of the string (removing `$` and adding `^` instead), to avoid future confusion, using instead negative lookahead `(?!\d)` to prevent the interpreter from matching numbers partially.

body:
Turkish parsing patterns is using default latin narrow pattern instead of one reflecting the first letters of Turkisk months, resulting in invalid dates for narrow format.

Also, for longer month formats, including that used in default date formats, the parsing values are not strict enough, resulting in may being read as march, and december being read as august.

Turkish still seems to have some issues, but this should enable parsing to be a bit more useful. (I am not a native Turkish speaker, just a RegEx nerd who needs the parser to work for long localized date format `PPP`)

body:
Norwegian locale currently prints out abbreviated months as 3 letters and a dot except for march, june and july that is printed out in full without a dot. (I assume this to ensure the abbreviated month character count is always 4?)
The parsing regexes currently don't reflect this, resulting in invalid dates.

This small fix aims to ammend that, so that parsing still works for these date formats. Same issue in both Norsk Bokm√•l (nb) and Nynorsk (nn) included in this fix

body:
These three Polish dates currently cannot be correctly parsed due to a bug inside the month matching regular expression pattern:
- `11 maja 2018` (matches only `maj`)
- `11 pa≈∫dziernika 2018` (matches only `pa≈∫dziernik`)
- `11 listopada 2018` (matches only `listopad`)

Those three dates would yield the `Invalid Date` error when trying to parse them. It can be easily fixed by changing the order of months inside the `matchMonthPatterns.wide` regular expression, so that the formatted month name would be before the regular name.

Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... Bumps [sshpk](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk) from 1.10.1 to 1.16.1.
Release notes *Sourced from [sshpk's releases](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/releases).* > ## v1.16.1 > * Fixes for [#60](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/60) (correctly encoding certificates with expiry dates >=2050), [#62](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/62) (accepting PKCS#8 EC private keys with missing public key parts) > > ## v1.16.0 > * Add support for SPKI fingerprints, PuTTY PPK format (public-key only for now), PKCS#8 PBKDF2 encrypted private keys > * Fix for [#48](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/48) > > ## v1.15.2 > * New API for accessing x509 extensions in certificates > * Fixes for [#52](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/52), [#50](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/50) > > ## v1.14.1 > * Remove all remaining usage of jodid25519 (abandoned dep) > * Add support for DNSSEC key format > * Add support for Ed25519 keys in PEM format (according to draft-curdle-pkix) > * Fixes for X.509 encoding issues (asn.1 NULLs in RSA certs, cert string type mangling) > * Performance issues parsing long SSH public keys > > ## v1.13.0 > * Support SSH-format rsa-sha2-256 signatures (e.g. so the SSH agent can sign using RSA-SHA256) > > ## v1.12.0 > * Support for generating ECDSA keys using `generatePrivateKey()` > * Minimum for `sshpk-agent` to be able to sign new certificates using an agent key > > ## v1.11.0 > * Added support for X.509 extKeyUsage

Bumps [sshpk](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk) from 1.10.2 to 1.16.1.
Release notes *Sourced from [sshpk's releases](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/releases).* > ## v1.16.1 > * Fixes for [#60](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/60) (correctly encoding certificates with expiry dates >=2050), [#62](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/62) (accepting PKCS#8 EC private keys with missing public key parts) > > ## v1.16.0 > * Add support for SPKI fingerprints, PuTTY PPK format (public-key only for now), PKCS#8 PBKDF2 encrypted private keys > * Fix for [#48](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/48) > > ## v1.15.2 > * New API for accessing x509 extensions in certificates > * Fixes for [#52](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/52), [#50](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/50) > > ## v1.14.1 > * Remove all remaining usage of jodid25519 (abandoned dep) > * Add support for DNSSEC key format > * Add support for Ed25519 keys in PEM format (according to draft-curdle-pkix) > * Fixes for X.509 encoding issues (asn.1 NULLs in RSA certs, cert string type mangling) > * Performance issues parsing long SSH public keys > > ## v1.13.0 > * Support SSH-format rsa-sha2-256 signatures (e.g. so the SSH agent can sign using RSA-SHA256) > > ## v1.12.0 > * Support for generating ECDSA keys using `generatePrivateKey()` > * Minimum for `sshpk-agent` to be able to sign new certificates using an agent key > > ## v1.11.0 > * Added support for X.509 extKeyUsage
Commits - [`1aece0d`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/1aece0d1df155e60e4cb0ae42cb3ed7aa043e174) joyent/node-sshpk#60 certs should generate GeneralizedTime values for dates >... - [`684dbe6`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/684dbe66d9615378bdb4d1ac1ede9f901591cb86) joyent/node-sshpk#62 handle pkcs8 ECDSA keys with missing public parts - [`574ff21`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/574ff21e77117b478baf4664856bfc4b0aa41a12) joyent/node-sshpk#18 support for PKCS8 encrypted private keys - [`f647cf2`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/f647cf22c3258ef514d2ba098a4a6aad3492f425) joyent/node-sshpk#27 Add support for PuTTY PPK format - [`44aec4a`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/44aec4ad8bcf7324009c92a52e4c81487cbc24b9) joyent/node-sshpk#59 want support for SPKI fingerprint format - [`385ff11`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/385ff11efc4edd201c07f2ceee23746c13122f9c) joyent/node-sshpk#48 wish: add support for x509 certificates in text form - [`c7a6c68`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/c7a6c6833370f69322c47e73e9f4cfdedaf4e8f4) joyent/node-sshpk#58 des-ede3-cbc encrypted keys broken - [`2ab4f2a`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/2ab4f2a018766559252f2c3426a3735f0860ac0d) joyent/node-sshpk#56 md5 fingerprints not quite right - [`026ef47`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/026ef4764a55648dd15f45f7f14ff9da5d1fe2ad) joyent/node-sshpk#53 stop using optional deps to fix webpack - [`53e23fe`](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commit/53e23feff41226826b45293bc4a9fc45f2e44afe) joyent/node-sshpk#50 Support PKCS#5 AES-256-CBC encrypted private keys - Additional commits viewable in [compare view](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/compare/v1.10.2...v1.16.1)

Commits - See full diff in [compare view](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commits/v1.16.1)

Bumps [brace-expansion](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) from 1.1.6 to 1.1.11.
Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... (truncated)

Bumps [sshpk](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk) from 1.10.1 to 1.16.1.
Release notes *Sourced from [sshpk's releases](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/releases).* > ## v1.16.1 > * Fixes for [#60](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/60) (correctly encoding certificates with expiry dates >=2050), [#62](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/62) (accepting PKCS#8 EC private keys with missing public key parts) > > ## v1.16.0 > * Add support for SPKI fingerprints, PuTTY PPK format (public-key only for now), PKCS#8 PBKDF2 encrypted private keys > * Fix for [#48](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/48) > > ## v1.15.2 > * New API for accessing x509 extensions in certificates > * Fixes for [#52](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/52), [#50](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/joyent/node-sshpk/issues/50) > > ## v1.14.1 > * Remove all remaining usage of jodid25519 (abandoned dep) > * Add support for DNSSEC key format > * Add support for Ed25519 keys in PEM format (according to draft-curdle-pkix) > * Fixes for X.509 encoding issues (asn.1 NULLs in RSA certs, cert string type mangling) > * Performance issues parsing long SSH public keys > > ## v1.13.0 > * Support SSH-format rsa-sha2-256 signatures (e.g. so the SSH agent can sign using RSA-SHA256) > > ## v1.12.0 > * Support for generating ECDSA keys using `generatePrivateKey()` > * Minimum for `sshpk-agent` to be able to sign new certificates using an agent key > > ## v1.11.0 > * Added support for X.509 extKeyUsage
Commits - See full diff in [compare view](https://github.com/joyent/node-sshpk/commits/v1.16.1)

Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... (truncated)

Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... (truncated)

Bumps [brace-expansion](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) from 1.1.6 to 1.1.11.
Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... (truncated)
