Bumps [brace-expansion](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) from 1.1.6 to 1.1.11.
Release notes *Sourced from [brace-expansion's releases](https://github.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion/releases).* > ## 1.1.11 > No release notes provided. > > ## v1.1.11 > # brace-expansion > > [Brace expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Brace-Expansion.html), > as known from sh/bash, in JavaScript. > > [![build status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](http://travis-ci.org/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > [![downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/brace-expansion.svg)](https://www.npmjs.org/package/brace-expansion) > [![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/juliangruber/brace-expansion.svg)](https://greenkeeper.io/) > > [![testling badge](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion.png)](https://ci.testling.com/juliangruber/brace-expansion) > > ## Example > > ```js > var expand = require('brace-expansion'); > > expand('file-{a,b,c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('-v{,,}') > // => ['-v', '-v', '-v'] > > expand('file{0..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file2.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..c}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-b.jpg', 'file-c.jpg'] > > expand('file{2..0}.jpg') > // => ['file2.jpg', 'file1.jpg', 'file0.jpg'] > > expand('file{0..4..2}.jpg') > // => ['file0.jpg', 'file2.jpg', 'file4.jpg'] > > expand('file-{a..e..2}.jpg') > // => ['file-a.jpg', 'file-c.jpg', 'file-e.jpg'] > > expand('file{00..10..5}.jpg') > // => ['file00.jpg', 'file05.jpg', 'file10.jpg'] > > expand('{{A..C},{a..c}}') > // => ['A', 'B', 'C', 'a', 'b', 'c'] > > expand('ppp{,config,oe{,conf}}') > // => ['ppp', 'pppconfig', 'pppoe', 'pppoeconf'] > ``` > ... (truncated)

body:
Currently if I use

```javascript
isDate (new Date ('aaaaaaa'))
``` 
or

```javascript
isDate(new Date('22/22/2222'))
```
it will return `true`, because when `new Date(someArgument)` returns `Invalid Date` it still a `instance of` `Date`. So I check if the argument passed to `isDate` contains an valid miliseconds value.

The translation was:

"Samedi 24i√®me ao√ªt"

When we expect "Samedi 24 ao√ªt"

I removed "Do" because I'm not sure if we should apply it in this case, no sense for me with V2.

Now `format` and `lightFormat` would throw `TypeError` if the first argument is not a number or `Date`.

See PR with raised concern regarding the behavior: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/1293
After some of the changes in the PR, I believe these lines are obsolete.

body:
Unlike the addDays function, addBusinessDays does not handle a negative amount and same given date.

```
addBusinessDays(new Date(2014, 8 /* Sep */, 15), -10)
// expected:  Sept 1st 2014
// actual: Sept 15 2014
```

addBusinessDays also loops over the entire given amount linearly e.g. is 1,000,000 is given as the amount than the loop runs 1,000,00 times. This behaviour is fixed using division in the PR.
```
  date.setDate(date.getDate() + toInteger(amount / 5) * 7)
```

differenceInBusinessDays also had the same performance issue where an array of all the dates in a range was being created and filtered through due to the [following line](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/src/differenceInBusinessDays/index.js#L53:L56)
```
  var daysOfInterval = eachDayOfInterval(interval)
  var difference = daysOfInterval.filter(function(day) {
    return !isWeekend(day)
  })
```
this performance issue is fixed below
```
  var weeks = toInteger(calendarDifference / 7)

  var result = weeks * 5
  dateRight = addDays(dateRight, weeks * 7)
```
remaining days not part of a full week are accounted for afterwards

body:
_Disclaimer: This PR is very much WIP. I'll probably restart from scratch once everything is ironed out. Indeed, the current setup has many caveats. See at the end._

This PR should close #1226 and #1190.

The idea is to typecheck the codebase using TypeScript instead of Flowtype. It poses several challenges as the build process of this library is quite involved. There are many moving parts so TypeScript, as typically used, is hard to fit in.

Things done in the PR:
- **Converted all JS lib files to TypeScript.** By lib files I mean actual library code, not the tests nor the benchmarks. I tried to sensibly type most of the public API but I didn't go all the way through so there are a lot of `any` types. It compiles in TypeScript's strictest settings.
- **Configured TypeScript so that it emits JS files in the same place where there are TS files.** This is the default behaviour. It allows for minimal changes to the current build process (although we might want to change it further). It has the big caveat of doubling the amount of checked out source code.
- **Ran prettier on all files.** I did a lot of regex-based refactoring and wanted to make sure that I could go back to a consistent style. Therefore I ran prettier on all files, both before and after the changes.
- **Introduced @typescript-eslint.** ESLint does not support TypeScript by default so I had to change the config. I went for the recommended stuff, but you might want to customize it to your liking as it adds new rules.
- **Commended out TS typings generation.** This used to create declaration files calling to `typings.d.ts`. Now we have the proper declaration files generated in place. This goes a long way towards #1190. What is left to do is the opposite: generate `typings.d.ts` from these declaration files. Microsoft's [API extractor](https://api-extractor.com/) does this very well.

I don't think this PR deserves to be reviewed yet because the approach is probably the wrong one. I tried to minimize the changes to perform on the build process but I only made it more complicated. Even worse, `scripts/build/package.sh` has stopped working so more work would be needed.

I suggest instead that we do an overhaul. This is a proposed architecture:
- Code and tests all in `src/`, as today. Difference is that it would be all TypeScript, without any `.d.ts` nor `.flow` files.
- A first build step dumps in `build/` the content of `src/` compiled to JavaScript, with the declaration files. We could have two TypeScript projects: one for the library code, that generates JS files with declaration files, and one for the test code, that only generates JS files. We can leverage project references to make the test code depend on the library code. An added benefit is that it becomes impossible to mistakenly import test code in the library code.
- With all the JS code in `build/`, we can run tests and benchmarks from `build/` instead of `src/`, as we do today.
- A second build step copies the library code and the declaration files from `build/` to `dist/` and does the following:
  - it generates `typings.d.ts` using [API extractor](https://api-extractor.com/)
  - it generates `.flow` files from the `.d.ts` files (the "how" is left to be figured out)
  - it builds various bundles using Rollup (this would also solve solve #1117 and #1201)

The big change is that it we wouldn't check out JavaScript, Flow and declaration files in source control. It would only exist while building. This may affect some other things I didn't notice yet; if so, let me know.

What do you think of this proposition? Of course I'm willing to do the work and document it. Let me know if you have any remarks.

body:
According to ISO 8601 '24:00' is supposed to be parsed as 12 AM the _next_ day, but before it was parsed as 12 AM of the _same_ day. See #1228

Also a few code style fixes.





ISO 8601:2004(E)
4.2.3
```
NOTE 1 The end of one calendar day [24:00] coincides with [00:00] at the start of the next calendar day, e.g. [24:00] on 12 April 1985 is the same as [00:00] on 13 April 1985.
```

Added a new formatter to get week of the month.
With respect to issue [#1134](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/1134)

Sister PR to #1154 

Should partly solve [#584](https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/584). Allthough it does not take holidays into consideration, it does exclude weekends and should have *some* value for end users.

All in all, it is just a thin wrapper around `eachDayOfInterval`, filtering out the weekends though.

Example usage:

```javascript
var amountOfBusinessDays = differenceInBusinessDays(
    new Date(2018, 0, 1),
    new Date(2019, 0, 1)
)
// => 261 (52 weekends excluded = 104 days skipped)
```

body:
There's currently no way to parse date strings using long localized date/time formats. This PR aims to add support to `p+` tokens to the `parse` function.

Added patterns:

| Unit                            |Prior| Pattern | Result examples                   | Notes |
|---------------------------------|-----|---------|-----------------------------------|-------|
| Long localized date             |   ? | P           | 05/29/1453                        | 7     |
|                                               |      | PP        | May 29, 1453                      | 7     |
|                                               |      | PPP      | May 29th, 1453                    | 7     |
|                                               |      | PPPP    | Sunday, May 29th, 1453            | 2,5   |
| Long localized time             |   ? | p       | 12:00 AM                          | 7     |
|                                               |      | pp      | 12:00:00 AM                       | 7     |

and their combinations.

body: Mb declarations was correct before. Please correct me.

I‚Äôve share date-fns as components using bit (https://github.com/teambit/bit), which turns libraries into components without refactoring. Having a function collection adds several benefits:

1. Each function can now be individually installed as a package with NPM and Yarn
2. People can use bit to develop each function right from their own project
3. People can visually explore the collection, search for functions and play with each in an online playground

I think this adds to the modular experience around the library as people can play and work with each function.
I‚Äôd be happy to hand over ownership and help update the collection if you like (it‚Äôs pretty simple).

body:
The PR is a result of an attempt to make minimal build size smaller. See https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/pull/1015 for the background.

- Extract `parseISO` from `toDate`
- Make `toDate` accept only numbers and dates
- Remove global options object
- Fixes DST issue in `eachDayOfInterval` that caused time in the days after DST change to have the shift as well.

The results of the PR:

- `lightFormat`: `1.73 KB` ‚Üí `887 B`
- `toDate`: `1.27 KB` ‚Üí `296 B`
- `addDays`: `1.31 KB` ‚Üí `385 B`

For comparison, here are the v1 stats:

- `format`: `2.77 KB`
- `addDays`: `983 B`

body:
From #1010:

>`format` is one of the most (if not the most) popular function in date-fns, but because it involves locales it's one the most (if not the most) heavyweight function in date-fns.
>
> Given that v2 locales became even more heavyweight, I want to introduce `lightFormat` that will cover the most common cases and address the size problem.
>
> The current goal is to be able to print ISO 8601 plus `hh` representing 12-hour clock and `a..aaa` representing am/pm.

This PR:

- Introduces `lightFormat` described in the quote above. The current function size is `1.73 KB`.
- Optimizes `toDate`size from `1.48 KB` to `1.27 KB`.

Unfortunately, it's not possible to bring the size significantly down. The bottleneck is `toDate` function and specifically the code responsible for parsing ISO 8601 strings.

body:
Previously to use ECMAScript Modules, you always had to import it from `esm` submodule to enable tree-shaking:

```javascript
import { format } from 'date-fns/esm'
import parse from 'date-fns/esm/parse'
import { eo } from 'date-fns/esm/locale'
import { addDays } from 'date-fns/esm/fp'
```

From now on you can use it without `esm`:

```javascript
import { format } from 'date-fns'
import parse from 'date-fns/parse'
import { eo } from 'date-fns/locale'
import { addDays } from 'date-fns/fp'
```

Now each function has a `package.json` with `module` field that points to the `esm` version of it.
commit_messages: Rework ESM to fully support tree-shaking (#910) (closes #567)

body:
Added a new method which takes the name or short-code of a month and returns the appropriate value (e.g. 'October' ==> '10', 'Apr.' ==> '04').  It's a very simple method but I've found this to be useful in various projects where date values are (unfortunately) not standardized and read from various strings.  Since I was already using `date-fns` to handle other date-related things in these projects I felt it could be a worthwhile addition.

Currently set to just support English names and short-codes, but could possibly be expanded to provide support for other languages.
Use `date.getUTCHours()` instead of `date.getHours()` because all calculations in the locales are made in UTC by default.

Google Chrome as of 67.0.3396.87 introduced timezones with offset that includes seconds.
 They usually appear for dates that denote time before the timezones were introduced
 (e.g. for 'Europe/Prague' timezone the offset is GMT+00:57:44 before 1 October 1891
 and GMT+01:00:00 after that date)

 Date#getTimezoneOffset returns the offset in minutes and would return 57 for the example above,
 which would lead to incorrect calculations.

 This PR introduces an utility function `getTimezoneOffsetInMilliseconds` which returns the timezone offset in milliseconds and takes seconds in account.

body:
- Convert number arguments into integer number using a custom `toInteger` implementation
- Change null/undefined/true/false implicit conversion strategy:
  - For required arguments:

  | | date          | number | string      | boolean |
  |-----------|---------------|--------|-------------|---------|
  | 0         | new Date(0)   | 0      | '0'         | false   |
  | '0'       | Invalid Date  | 0      | '0'         | false   |
  | 1         | new Date(1)   | 1      | '1'         | true    |
  | '1'       | Invalid Date  | 1      | '1'         | true    |
  | true      | Invalid Date  | NaN    | 'true'      | true    |
  | false     | Invalid Date  | NaN    | 'false'     | false   |
  | null      | Invalid Date  | NaN    | 'null'      | false   |
  | undefined | Invalid Date  | NaN    | 'undefined' | false   |
  | NaN       | Invalid Date  | NaN    | 'NaN'       | false   |

  - For optional arguments, null and undefined are treated as if argument is not provided

If I import a locale with the syntax `import {de} from 'date-fns/esm/locale'`, no tree-shaking is done in webpack (v4.5) and **all** locales are included in my final production bundle.

Importing a language like this `import {default as de} from 'date-fns/esm/locale/de'` works as expected and only includes the imported locale in my final bundle, which makes it about 100kb smaller.

body:
I've built on the addition in #676 by @benmccann and tried to figure out what an API / helper functions for time zone support might look like which would solve the use cases presented in #180. Key additions are the two time zone helper functions:

- `setTimeZone` for getting a `Date` instance with the time at a given time zone
- `dateAtTimeZone` for getting a `Date` with the UTC value of a time in a given time zone

The `toDate`, `format` and `parse` functions also have additional time zone support added.

For a more complete discussion of the new functionality see the [Time zone documentation](https://github.com/marnusw/date-fns/blob/timezones/docs/timeZones.md) included in this PR.

The `date-fns` library aims to support IE8+ (see #660). This PR proposes using the `Intl` API for IANA time zone support which requires a [polyfill](https://github.com/yahoo/date-time-format-timezone) in older browsers. As a compromise, all new time zone functionality fully supports the use of time zone offset values (`+0200`, `-04:00` etc.) which will work back to IE8. If you wish to use IANA time zones a polyfill will be needed though.

This library is great!

@markowsiak Thanks for adding the en-CA locale support! 

This PR intends to help prepare en-CA for inclusion in the next release.

This PR:
- adds to release/contribution docs (giving attribution to @markowsiak for the feature)
- fixes what I believe was error in how "1 second" should be described (https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/commit/166e0117d23ea364bd6184f28fbfa26ecc8c5957)
- does the exports so this locale is accessible

Hope this helps.  Let me know if you'd like to see some further tweaks or changes.

cc: @leshakoss

In the current Norwegian locale, the short versions of the day names are the same as the narrow. The three day versions are commonly used in Norway, and having the correct ones in `date-fns` would be great.

This PR adds that.

We noticed that the `nl` locale did not yet contain the proper long format specifiers (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_the_Netherlands). Also, the relative date formatting did not use the Dutch language yet.

In this pull request I've updated both. Since this is my first contribution to this project, I'm happy to receive feedback and update the PR accordingly if that would be necessary.

Thank you @Easybird for bringing this issue to my attention :)

body:
Added support for running tests in node with jest.

This is preferable during development due to a much improved speed when running the tests. It also allows for watching for changes and only running tests related to a change. This means you get feedback of a failing test within seconds.

The configuration is minimal. Tests can be run in watch mode by running:

jest --watch

# Why?

Users that don't need to format dates with English locale might not want to include the english locale in their javascript bundle to optimize performance towards the end user. The size of the English locale is around 2 KB.

- By hiding English locale behind `date-fns/src/locale/default_locale` the module redirect configuration will make more sense and won't redirect the cases where you want to explicitly user English locale.
- The same technique could be used to select a sensible default locale in a project, although that is probably not recommended.

# How?

- Introduce and use the module `locale/default_locale`
- Add documentation on how to exclude the English locale by showing an example Webpack configuration

`hh:mm A` => `12:30 AM`
`hh:mm aa` => `12:30 ‰∏äÂçà`

Corrected behavoir: 
`hh:mm a` => `12:30 ‰∏äÂçà`
`hh:mm A` => `12:30 ‰∏äÂçà`
`hh:mm aa` => `12:30 ‰∏äÂçà`

body:
Adds an options parameter with weekStartsOn to getDay

For example

```javascript
// A Friday with standard options
getDay(new Date(2017, 3, 7)) // 5

// A Friday with the week beginning on a Monday
getDay(new Date(2017, 3, 7), { weekStartsOn: 1 }) // 4
```

Also updates other functions using weekStartsOn to rely on getDay, removing duplicated logic

NB: In working on this PR I discovered issue #472.

body:
Some dates don't exist in some timezones, for example:

```
$ env TZ="America/New_York" node
> new Date(2017, 2 /* March */, 12, 2).toString()
'Sun Mar 12 2017 03:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)'
> new Date(2017, 2 /* March */, 12, 3).toString()
'Sun Mar 12 2017 03:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)'
```

In `America/New_York` timezone and node environment the date `2017-03-12T02:00:00` doesn't exist because of DST.

So, when there's a test like this:
```javascript
it('subtracts a day', function () {
  var date = new Date(2017, 2 /* March */, 12, 2)
  var result = subDays(date, 1)
  assert.deepEqual(result, new Date(2017, 2 /* March */, 11, 2)
})
```
it fails in `America/New_York` even when there's nothing wrong with function `subDays`. We run our tests through a number of timezones: https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/blob/master/scripts/test_tz_extended.sh#L8-L344
Some tests will fail. Right now, we have no other solution but to modify tests to exclude all dates that don't exist in any timezone. Before, we also had to deal with `phantomjs` which has a lot of timezone related bugs (basically, in `phantomjs` you can create impossible dates by manipulating them via `Date` methods, even if you can't create these dates using `Date` constructor). That's why we had to do PRs #422 and #427. Recently, we moved our automatic tests to Chromium.

This PR:
- undoes #427 and test changes of #422
- updates Travis CI to the `trusty` environment that includes one of the latest versions of Chromium (Chromium 53.0.2785 at the moment)
- excludes locale tests when testing through timezones (locales are supposed to be timezone-independent) to speed up the Travis CI tests. Makes the difference between [passed test](https://travis-ci.org/date-fns/date-fns/builds/200302803) and [failed due to the time restriction](https://travis-ci.org/date-fns/date-fns/builds/200263583). Linked tests were made on this PR before rebasing.
- fixes tests for Chromium

body:
New official `date-fns` naming guideline:

- If function accepts two dates, and it only makes sense if these dates are **in specific order**, use **"interval"** in the name of the function and `type Interval = {start: Date | string | number, end: Date | string | number}` as the type to represent these two dates in the function's arguments. An exception of type `Error` should be thrown if `interval.start.getTime() > interval.end.getTime()`.

- If function uses a difference between two dates **regardless of the exact values of two dates** and it is always **non-negative**, use word **"duration"** in the name of the function. See #284 

- If function manipulates dates in any other way, **do not** use suffix **"date"**. For example, use `addDays` instead of `addDaysToDate`. "Date" is already in the name of library:

```javascript
import addDaysToDate from 'date-fns/addDays' // ok
import addDaysToDate from 'date-fns/addDaysToDate' // tautologic
```

Exceptions: `toDate`, `isDate`.

- Use **date** to signify **the days of the month**. This mirrors the terminology of JavaScript standard library.

This PR adds 2 additional methods. This is the first PR which tries to incrementally add duration support to date-fns. The first PR adds  two new public methods which add or subtract an ISO8601 duration string to or from a given date.

In this PR there are also a couple of other functions scoped under `durations/` which are needed to implement `addDuration` and `subDuration`. Some of them might become public (documented) in one of the next PRs.

body:
This is a work in progress PR which will add support for durations to date-fns. It will mostly migrate functions from https://www.npmjs.com/package/pomeranian-durations to date-fns in order to create one comprehensive library to work with dates, times and durations.

closes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/277
closes https://github.com/date-fns/date-fns/issues/284

I've found the [I18n support](https://date-fns.org/docs/I18n) of `date-fns` to be very useful.

However, at the moment, the translations can only be used in the context of a fully formed timestamp. This means that I cannot utilise these translation dictionaries to render out a textual list of months, for example, without being very hacky, and providing a superfluous timestamp to each.

In order to solve this, I've created a new method `.getTranslation` on each `locale` object, that, given a formatter token (as per [`format`](https://date-fns.org/docs/format)), and an optional index, returns a single translated phrase at that index. If the optional index isn't provided, the whole list is returned.

For example:

```js
const daLocale = require('date-fns/locale/da');

daLocale.getTranslation('MMM')
$> ['jan', 'feb', 'mar', 'apr', 'maj', 'jun', 'jul', 'aug', 'sep', 'okt', 'nov', 'dec']

daLocale.getTranslation('dddd', 3)
$> onsdag
```

There is now a translations dictionary for each locale (located in `./locale/*/translations/index.js`), from which this new method obtains its values. This dictionary is also used for each method that requires it in each `build_format_locale`.

Hope it proves of some use!

body: I thought this was all fairly straightforward except for the meridiem stuff. As far as I know, we Swedes don't really use that kind of notation very often, and the only times I _have_ seen it it's always been in the form of "f.m." (AM) and "e.m." (PM). Never uppercase or written without the periods. So that's what I did, no matter if you use the `A`, `a` or `aa` formatting.

body:
Bug affected all functions that use `new Date(year, month, day)`, namely:
- `addMonths`
- `getISOYear`
- `lastDayOfISOYear`
- `setMonth`
- `startOfTomorrow`
- `startOfYesterday`
- `endOfISOYear`
- `endOfTomorrow`
- `endOfYesterday`
- `getDaysInMonth`
- `startOfYear`

and also potentially all functions that uses any of those, namely:
- `addISOYears`
- `addQuarters`
- `addYears`
- `differenceInCalendarISOYears`
- `differenceInISOYears`
- `endOfISOYear`
- `format`
- `setQuarter`
- `startOfISOYear`
- `subISOYears`
- `subMonths`
- `subQuarters`
- `subYears`
- `getISOWeek`
- `getISOWeeksInYear`
- `isSameISOYear`
- `setISOYear`
- `setISOWeek`
- `isThisISOYear`
- `getDayOfYear`

It happens because `Date` constructor uses `years` instead of `fullYears` as its first argument, so creating years less than 100 will produce incorrect results.

Example:
```
> dateFns.setISOYear(new Date(), 5).toString()
'Thu Nov 23 1905 00:00:00 GMT+0600 (+06)'
```

Solution: instead of `new Date(year, month, day)` should be used:
```
var date = new Date(0)
date.setFullYears(year, month, day)
date.setHours(0, 0, 0, 0)
```

body:
Consider:

``` javascript
console.log(format(addMonths('2016-02-29', 12), 'YYYY-MM-DD')); // 2017-02-28
console.log(format(addYears('2016-02-29', 1), 'YYYY-MM-DD'));   // 2017-03-01

console.log(format(subMonths('2016-02-29', 12), 'YYYY-MM-DD')); // 2015-02-28
console.log(format(subYears('2016-02-29', 1), 'YYYY-MM-DD'));   // 2015-03-01
```

Since February 29th does not exist in a common year, the Date object advances it forward to March 1st.  Feb 28th is usually expected in most scenarios (IMHO).

See also:
http://codeofmatt.com/2016/01/01/happy-new-leap-year/

(Scroll down to "Adding a year in JavaScript")
